The protests, fueled by concerns about democratic backsliding and dynastic politics, led to parliament delaying the proposed law’s implementation, meaning it would not apply to this year's elections. The move comes amid criticism of Jokowi for alleged power grabs and the emergence of a political dynasty focused on his family.

item.title: Inside Rail Force One, the special train that ferried PM Modi from Poland to Ukraine
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Ukraine is the first by an Indian prime minister since the country's independence in 1991. He traveled to Ukraine from Poland via the "Rail Force One," a diesel-powered train also used by world leaders like Joe Biden and Emmanuel Macron to reach Kyiv amidst the war. The train journey highlights the importance of rail travel in Ukraine due to the closure of airspace and limited road access. Over 200 foreign diplomatic missions have arrived in Ukraine by train since the invasion, making it a vital lifeline for international engagement and aid delivery. While Rail Force One provides a relatively safe passage, it has posed challenges to Ukraine's rail network, causing delays to other essential services.

item.title: Bangladesh cancels Sheikh Hasina's red passport: What does this mean for the ex-PM?
item.description: The interim government in Bangladesh has revoked all diplomatic passports, including those held by former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and other officials of her ousted government. This move complicates Hasina's situation as she is currently in India and could face extradition to Bangladesh on several criminal charges. The cancellation of these passports also impacts the ability of former officials to travel internationally and signals a strong intent by the interim government to strip away their privileges. The decision has potential implications for Bangladesh's relationship with India, which has an extradition treaty with Bangladesh.

item.title: Texas gets tallest Hanuman statue outside India. What you need to know
item.description: A 90-foot-tall bronze statue of Lord Hanuman, named the 'Statue of Union,' has been unveiled in Sugar Land, Texas. It is now the third tallest sculpture in the US, surpassed only by the Statue of Liberty and the Pegasus and Dragon in Florida. Located at Sri Ashtalakshmi Temple, the statue is intended as a spiritual epicenter for North America, evoking strength, devotion, and selfless service. Its unveiling was marked by a grand three-day Prana Prathishta ceremony, drawing thousands of devotees. The statue's design, with arms raised, has sparked debate about its inspiration, with some suggesting a connection to the Thai Buddha's gesture of "do not fight."

item.title: Why Hema panel report on sexual harassment in Mollywood matters beyond Kerala
item.description: The Hema Committee report has exposed disturbing details about sexual harassment, exploitation, and discrimination faced by women in the Malayalam film industry. The report highlights the prevalence of casting couch, where power figures demand sexual favors in exchange for roles. Women are also subjected to suggestive comments, unwelcome advances, and cyber attacks when they speak out. The report reveals the existence of a powerful "mafia" group of men who control the industry and stifle dissent. Suggestions include establishing an independent tribunal to address these issues and enforcing the POSH Act on film sets. The report has elicited strong reactions from politicians, film personalities, and women's rights groups.

item.title: Why have Canada’s railroads shut down? What could be the impact?
item.description:
The Teamsters Canada Rail Conference, representing 10,000 engineers, conductors, and dispatchers, went on strike with CN and CPKC after contract negotiations failed. The primary sticking points are scheduling practices and concerns about fatigue-related safety. The union argues the companies want to shift away from a km-based pay system to an hourly one, potentially leading to longer working hours and increased safety risks.
The railroads, on the other hand, claim their offers maintain current work rules and comply with safety regulations, while offering wage increases comparable to recent industry deals. Both believe binding arbitration would be the best way to resolve the dispute.
A complete shutdown of both CN and CPKC, which control most of Canada's rail freight, poses a significant threat to the economy. The stoppage could result in billions of dollars in losses, disrupt the movement of crucial goods, and impact industries like agriculture, manufacturing, and transportation. The situation is drawing international attention due to its potential to impact US businesses and supply chains, given the significant cross-border trade reliant on Canadian railroads.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder case: Was the crime scene altered?
item.description:
The CBI filed a status report with the Supreme Court regarding the alleged rape and murder of a trainee doctor at Kolkata's RG Kar Medical College and Hospital. The report stated the crime scene may have been tampered with and highlighted inconsistencies in the West Bengal Police's handling of the case, including initially stating it was a suicide and later claiming it was murder. The report also noted a delay in informing the police about the discovery of the body and raised concerns about the credibility of initial police procedures.
The Supreme Court questioned the reasons for the delay in filing an FIR and the lack of crime scene security until after the post-mortem.
The CBI is investigating Sanjoy Roy, a Kolkata Police volunteer, as the primary suspect based on CCTV footage and his confession. The case sparked protests from doctors across India, leading the Supreme Court to initiate a National Task Force to address safety concerns for medical professionals.

item.title: India's Chandrayaan-3 unveils lunar secrets: Did the Moon once host a magma ocean?
item.description:
India's Chandrayaan-3 mission has provided compelling evidence supporting the theory that the Moon was once covered by a vast ocean of magma. The Pragyan rover's data revealed a consistent presence of ferroan anorthosite, a key mineral, suggesting a shared geological history across the lunar south pole. This discovery aligns with previous missions and strengthens the Lunar Magma Ocean hypothesis.
The rover also detected magnesium-rich minerals, indicating that material from deeper within the Moon may have been brought to the surface, possibly due to the impact that formed the South Pole-Aitken Basin.
These findings contribute significantly to our understanding of the Moon's formation and evolution, highlighting the global processes that shaped its crust. Chandrayaan-3 cements India's position as a major player in space exploration.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder: Why RG Kar’s new principal Suhrita Paul was sacked, days after appointment
item.description:
Following student protests triggered by the rape and murder of a junior doctor at RG Kar Medical College, the West Bengal government removed Suhrita Paul as principal a week after her appointment.
Paul’s appointment followed the resignation of the previous principal, Sandip Ghosh, who was facing intense pressure. However, Paul's tenure was short-lived due to continued student unrest and her perceived lack of engagement with the campus.
Students complained about Paul's absence and criticized her failure to address their concerns after the violent incident. Protests escalated, leading to her removal and the appointment of a new principal, Manas Kumar Bandhopadhyay. Three other senior officials, Bulbul Mukhopadhyay, Arunabha Datta Chaudhuri, and Saptarshi Chatterjee were also transferred.

item.title: Bayesian yacht sinking: Who has been found? Who remains missing?
item.description: The British-flagged superyacht Bayesian sank off the coast of Sicily after being caught in a waterspout. Five bodies have been recovered, including those of Michael Lynch, the British tech entrepreneur, and his 18-year-old daughter Hannah. Recaldo Thomas, a chef on board, was also found deceased. Four people remain missing, including Jonathan Bloomer, chairman of Morgan Stanley International, and his wife Judy, as well as lawyer Chris Morvillo and his wife Neda, a jewelry designer. Fifteen survivors were rescued, including Lynch's wife Angela Bacares and several others who were involved in Lynch's recent legal case. Search and rescue efforts continue for the missing individuals.

item.title: Quicksplained: Meet Rakesh Bhatt, the Hindu priest, who kicked off DNC Day 3 with ‘Om Shanti’ chants
item.description:
Hindu priest Rakesh Bhatt, hailing from Bengaluru, brought a spiritual element to the third day of the Democratic National Convention. He called for unity and invoked the Indian concept of "Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam" (the whole world is one family) while supporting Kamala Harris.
Pandit Bhatt, a scholar with expertise in religious studies and rituals, received special training in Tantrasaara (Maadhva) Agama and the Rig Veda. He speaks multiple languages, holds advanced degrees in Sanskrit, English, and Kannada, and is recognized as a scholar by various institutions.
His participation at the DNC was praised for showcasing the Democratic Party's commitment to inclusivity and diversity. His prayer was seen as a celebration of unity transcending cultural and religious boundaries.

item.title: ‘Big Dog’ Bill Clinton, an introduction to Tim Walz, and surprise Oprah! Takeaways from DNC Day 3
item.description:
The third day of the Democratic National Convention highlighted unity and "freedom" through speeches by Bill Clinton, Tim Walz, and Oprah Winfrey. Clinton, known for his political experience, contrasted the Democratic ticket with Trump's approach. Walz, Minnesota's governor, emphasized his roots and fighting for working-class Americans. Winfrey delivered a passionate endorsement of Kamala Harris, embodying the American dream and advocating for decency and respect.
The night featured diverse perspectives, including an invocation based on "Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam" (the whole world is one family) and heartfelt pleas from the parents of a Hamas hostage. Democrats tied freedom to various issues like reproductive rights and LGBTQ+ rights, with governors like Jared Polis and Josh Shapiro showcasing their party's commitment. Social media influencers were also integrated into the convention, reflecting a shift in media consumption. Nancy Pelosi addressed rumors of tension with Biden, praising his accomplishments and emphasizing unity within the party. Unfortunately, a bizarre incident involving insects found in delegate food added an unsettling note to the proceedings.

item.title: Who is Hersh Goldberg-Polin, the Hamas hostage, whose parents appeared at the DNC?
item.description: Jon and Rachel Goldberg-Polin, parents of Hersh Goldberg-Polin, one of the eight Americans kidnapped by Hamas, delivered a moving speech at the Democratic National Convention. Hersh was abducted during the October 2023 attack on the Nova music festival near the Gaza Strip, where he had been attending a festival. He sustained a severe arm injury during the abduction. The parents pleaded for the release of all hostages, emphasizing the humanitarian crisis and calling for a deal that would bring them home. They expressed gratitude for the efforts of negotiators and the support of the public. The emotional speech highlighted the human cost of the conflict and put pressure on all parties to find a resolution.

item.title: ‘Not an era of war’: How PM Modi has continuously called for peace amid Russia-Ukraine conflict
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, during a visit to Poland, reaffirmed India’s dedication to resolving the Russia-Ukraine conflict through dialogue and diplomacy. This stance, consistent since the start of the war, emphasizes peace and underscores India's belief that war is not a solution. Modi's message was reiterated in his meeting with President Putin in Russia and at the G7 summit in Italy, where he stressed the importance of a human-centric approach to finding a resolution. India has consistently abstained from UN votes condemning Russia's actions, advocating for peaceful dialogue and maintaining neutral ground.

item.title: FirstUp: PM Modi's Day 2 in Poland, the DNC comes to an end... Big headlines today
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi is in Poland for a two-day visit, his first in over forty years. He will meet with Polish President Andrzej Duda and Prime Minister Donald Tusk. The Democratic National Convention in Chicago continues with speaker appearances such as Minnesota Governor Tim Walz, former President Bill Clinton, and former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Tamil actor Vijay will unveil the flag of his political party, Tamizhaga Vetri Kazhagam (TVK). A Pune court is expected to rule on the bail applications of those accused in the Porsche car crash case. In London, Indian-origin doctors will hold a protest demanding justice for a trainee doctor murdered in Kolkata.

item.title: Globe-trotters: Why more Indians are travelling the world
item.description:
India is experiencing a tourism boom, with both domestic and international travel seeing significant growth. Factors driving this rise include a growing middle class, increased disposable incomes, and a younger population eager to explore. Ease of visa rules by countries like Thailand, Vietnam, and the UAE have also contributed to the surge in outbound travel.
India's international travel spending is projected to reach $42 billion in 2024 and $410 billion by 2030, making its citizens the world's fourth-largest travel spenders. Popular destinations for Indians include Southeast Asia, the UAE, the US, and Japan. Direct flights, affordable fares, and diverse experiences are attracting Indian tourists. India's tourism sector is expected to continue its upward trajectory, fueled by a rising middle class and a passion for travel.

item.title: Why Pakistan has arrested a man over UK’s Southport riots
item.description:
Farhan Asif, an independent journalist allegedly linked to the now-defunct website Channel3Now, has been arrested in Pakistan for spreading misinformation that fueled the Southport riots.
The website published a false claim that the perpetrator of the stabbing incident was an asylum seeker named Ali al-Shakati. The article went viral, contributing to widespread violence and racial attacks across the UK based on the false information. Asif initially denied responsibility but later admitted to Pakistani police that he published the article based on unverified information from a UK social media account. Channel3Now has since been shut down, and those involved in publishing the article have been fired. Asif is facing charges of cyber terrorism.

item.title: Is your love for meat putting you at risk of diabetes?
item.description:
Research links regular consumption of red and processed meats to a higher risk of Type 2 Diabetes. Studies show that even small daily servings can increase this risk. Consuming processed meat, the size of a medium sausage or two to three slices of bacon, was associated with a 15% increase in diabetes risk, while 3.5 ounces of red meat, roughly a small steak, led to a 10% increase.
Heme iron, found predominantly in red meat, is identified as a significant contributor to this risk. Researchers suggest limiting red meat consumption and prioritizing plant-based foods for a healthier diet.

item.title: How mpox outbreak has helped make pharma company Bavarian Nordic richer
item.description:
Bavarian Nordic, a Danish biotech firm, has seen a significant surge in its share price following the World Health Organisation's declaration of mpox as a global public health emergency. The company is one of the few with an approved mpox vaccine, marketed under names such as Jynneos and Imvanex. Bavarian Nordic has been supplying vaccines for emergencies like the Ebola virus and has recently donated 40,000 doses to the Africa CDC.
The company aims to increase its production capacity and ensure fair access to its vaccine. Bavarian Nordic has also submitted data to the EU medical regulator for approval of its vaccine for adolescents and plans to initiate trials for use in younger children.

item.title: In Graphics | Which religion comprises the most migrants?
item.description:
A Pew Research Center study found that Christians comprised 47% of the global migrant population in 2020, followed by Muslims at 29%. The religiously unaffiliated made up 13%, while Hindus, Buddhists, and Jews represented 5%, 4%, and 1% respectively.
Despite a 83% surge in international migrants over the past 30 years, the religious composition of migrants has remained largely stable since 1990. The United States hosts the largest number of Christian migrants (27% or 35.4 million), followed by Germany and Russia.

item.title: Is Democratic VP candidate Tim Walz's 'damn' strategy winning voters?
item.description: Tim Walz, the Democratic vice presidential candidate, has been using the word "damn" frequently during his recent campaign appearances. This isn't a new tactic for Walz, as he has consistently incorporated the word into his public speaking for many years. Despite potential negative perceptions associated with profanity, Walz's use of "damn" hasn't hindered his electoral success, suggesting a calculated effort to appear relatable and authentic. This approach has historical precedents in American politics, with many previous leaders, from Andrew Jackson to Lyndon Johnson, utilizing profanity in their public and private discourse. While journalists often highlight these instances, the societal tolerance for profanity has arguably increased, particularly among younger generations. Walz's continued use of "damn" will be interesting to observe as the campaign progresses, as it remains to be seen if he maintains this approach or adjusts his language.

item.title: Why are couples hiring ‘professional parents’ to raise their children in China?
item.description:
In China, a new trend is emerging where affluent families hire "professional child companions" to fulfill a range of parental roles. These highly educated individuals, often graduates of prestigious universities, provide academic support, extracurricular guidance, and emotional care. They can manage homework, accompany children to activities, and even attend medical appointments.
The demand for these professionals stems from parents' busy careers and a desire to provide exceptional care. While salaries are substantial, averaging between Rs 1.17 lakh to Rs 3.43 lakh per month, concerns exist about the potential impact on the parent-child relationship. Some worry that children may develop stronger attachments to their companions than their own parents, raising questions about the true meaning of "parental" care.

item.title: 'Sold unclaimed corpses, assaulted wife': The controversial life of ex-RG Kar principal
item.description: Dr. Sandip Ghosh, the former principal of RG Kar Medical College and Hospital, is facing multiple accusations following the rape and murder of a trainee doctor at the institution. He has been accused of profiting from unclaimed bodies, trafficking biomedical waste, and engaging in widespread corruption, including accepting bribes for various hospital operations and deliberately failing students to extort money. A former colleague, Dr. Akhtar Ali, has lodged formal complaints against Dr. Ghosh, alleging a pattern of financial misconduct and abuse of power. Allegations of domestic violence against Dr. Ghosh’s wife have also emerged from former neighbors. Despite resigning from his post, Dr. Ghosh was quickly transferred to another medical college, prompting criticism from the Calcutta High Court. A Special Investigation Team has been formed to probe the financial irregularities at RG Kar.

item.title: Why India’s rupee is the worst performer in the Asian market against the dollar
item.description: The Indian rupee has weakened against the US dollar in August, becoming the worst-performing Asian currency. While other Asian currencies have strengthened due to anticipation of US rate cuts, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has intervened in the market to prevent a larger decline in the rupee. The RBI's intervention and a combination of factors such as foreign outflows from equities, import demand for dollars, and unwinding of carry trades have contributed to the rupee's weakness. Despite these challenges, the RBI's efforts are expected to keep the rupee within a narrow range.

item.title: How a pair of scissors led to more than 30 flight cancellations at Japan's airport
item.description: Traffic at New Chitose Airport in Japan was halted on Saturday after a pair of scissors went missing. The incident triggered extensive security searches, resulting in the cancellation of 36 flights and delays of around 200 more. The airport's strict security procedures mandate that scissors be stored securely, raising concerns about a potential breach. Security checks were suspended for over two hours, leading to long lines and travel disruptions, particularly impacting passengers returning home from the Obon festival. After two days, the missing scissors were found in the same location where they disappeared. The airport operator apologized for the inconvenience and promised to investigate the incident to prevent future occurrences.

item.title: How air pockets may offer a fighting chance to those on board sunken Bayesian yacht
item.description: The luxury yacht Bayesian sank off the Sicilian coast, leaving six passengers missing after a severe storm. Retief efforts are ongoing with the hope that survivors may be trapped in air pockets within the wreckage. The yacht was carrying 22 people, including British tech mogul Mike Lynch and his daughter Hannah. While fifteen passengers were rescued, the remaining six are still unaccounted for. Experts suggest the possibility of air pockets, but time is a critical factor as chances of survival diminish. Divers face challenges due to the depth of the wreckage, and authorities remain skeptical about finding anyone alive.

item.title: Mahatma Gandhi’s friend, ‘motherji’ to Dalai Lama: Meet the Polish woman Umadevi, who made India her second home
item.description: Wanda Dynowska, born in Russia to Polish nobility, was a woman of multiple names and passions. A theosophist at heart, she was drawn to Eastern philosophies and travelled extensively. After establishing herself in Poland, she later made India her second home in 1935. Fluent in several languages, she immersed herself in Indian culture, learning Hindi and Tamil, and translating Hindu scriptures into Polish. A staunch supporter of freedom in both India and Poland, she worked tirelessly to aid Polish refugees in India during World War II. Recognized by Mahatma Gandhi as “Bearer of Light,” she adopted the name Umadevi and continued her humanitarian work, including assisting Tibetan refugees. Deeply devoted to spirituality, Dynowska, who was also known as Tenzin Chodon, bridged cultural divides, leaving a lasting legacy of kindness and understanding.

item.title: How Starbucks’s new CEO will undertake a 1,600 km super commute to work
item.description: Starbucks' incoming CEO, Brian Niccol, will undertake a significant commute, flying 1,000 miles three times a week from his California home to the Seattle headquarters in a corporate jet. This arrangement, along with a remote office and additional perks, is part of a substantial compensation package worth approximately $113 million. While Starbucks emphasizes the connection between Niccol's compensation and company performance, the decision has drawn criticism for its environmental implications, with some accusing the company of hypocrisy given its sustainability initiatives. This "super commute" trend among executives is becoming more common, driven by a competitive labor market and the desire to attract top talent.

item.title: Wreath laying, bilateral meetings, & talks with Indians: PM Modi’s itinerary for Day 1 of Poland visit
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is on a two-day visit to Poland, marking the first visit by an Indian prime minister in 45 years. The visit coincides with the 70th anniversary of diplomatic ties between India and Poland. Modi's schedule includes paying homage to memorials honoring individuals and events significant to both nations, addressing the Indian diaspora in Poland, and meeting with Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk and President Andrzej Duda. Following Poland, Modi will make a brief stopover in Ukraine, marking the first visit by an Indian prime minister to the country since 1992.

item.title: PM Modi at Jam Saheb of Nawanagar memorial: How the Indian royal became Poland’s ‘Good Maharaja’
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Poland marks the first by an Indian leader in 45 years. His first stop is the Jam Saheb of Nawanagar Memorial in Warsaw, dedicated to Jam Saheb Digvijaysinhji Ranjitsinhji, a former Maharaja of Nawanagar.
Ranjitsinhji, known as the "Good Maharaja" in Poland, is remembered for his humanitarian efforts during World War II. He provided refuge to hundreds of Polish children who were orphaned and displaced due to the war.
The Maharaja welcomed them to Nawanagar, India, offering them a home, medical care, education, and a sense of belonging. He even sought support from other rulers and organizations to ensure their well-being.
Years later, Poland honored Ranjitsinhji for his kindness by naming a square after him in Warsaw and awarding him posthumous recognition. His legacy continues to be celebrated as a testament to compassion and global empathy.

item.title: Thane horror: How cops’ apathy in sexual abuse case led to mass protests and vandalism
item.description:
Two kindergarten girls were allegedly sexually abused by a school attendant in Badlapur, Thane. The incident came to light when one girl complained of pain and later revealed the assault. The accused, Akshay Shinde, was arrested on August 17.
The parents alleged a 11-hour delay by the police in filing an FIR. This sparked massive protests in Badlapur, with locals vandalizing the school and blocking train services.
The Maharashtra government has ordered a Special Investigation Team led by IPS officer Arti Singh to probe the case and suspended three police officials. The Chief Minister has assured speedy justice and stated that the case will be fast-tracked under the POCSO Act.
The National Human Rights Commission has also issued notices to the Maharashtra government demanding a detailed report on the case.

item.title: Double Obama power, former Republicans and family man Doug Emhoff: Key takeaways from DNC Day 2
item.description:
The second night of the Democratic National Convention featured powerful endorsements of Kamala Harris by Barack and Michelle Obama. Both highlighted Harris' qualifications while delivering scathing critiques of Donald Trump's leadership. They warned against the dangers of another Trump term, emphasizing the need to move beyond "bluster and chaos."
The DNC continued its focus on Project 2025, a conservative policy agenda, portraying it as a threat to working families and social progress. Representatives spoke against its proposed policies, painting a picture of potential harm if implemented.
Adding to the celebratory atmosphere, a lively roll call of states was transformed into a dance party, featuring music representative of each state. Personal endorsements came from former Republicans who expressed disillusionment with Trump and admiration for Harris, aiming to appeal to voters dissatisfied with the former president. Doug Emhoff, Harris' husband, shared a heartfelt tribute, emphasizing her dedication and character, and humanizing her amidst personal attacks.

item.title: Quicksplained: When Poland began learning Sanskrit 164 years ago
item.description: The Jagiellonian University in Poland began offering Sanskrit grammar lectures in 1860, establishing a long history of Indological studies. In 1893, the first Sanskrit Chair in Poland was founded, led by Professor Leon MaÅkowski. Subsequent professors, including Andrzej GawroÅski and Helena Willman-Grabowska, further expanded Sanskrit studies and introduced courses on various aspects of Indian culture and languages. The Indology Department at the University of Warsaw is now the largest center for Indian studies in Central Europe.

item.title: What’s behind the Bharat Bandh today? What is open, what is closed?
item.description:
The Reservation Bachao Sangharsh Samiti has called a Bharat Bandh on August 21 to protest the Supreme Court's decision allowing states to create sub-categories within SC/ST reservations. Organisations like NACADOR and political parties like the JMM, Congress, and RJD support the strike, demanding justice and equity for marginalised communities.
The Supreme Court's ruling reverses its 2004 decision, leading to concerns about undermining the reservation principle. While the Samiti calls for a complete shutdown, the impact remains unclear.
Emergency services, including hospitals, pharmacies, and public transportation, will remain operational. Government offices, banks, and schools will generally function as usual, though some may close in solidarity or switch to online classes. Protests are expected, prompting heightened security in sensitive areas.

item.title: PM Modi’s Poland trip: Will it help in boosting ties between the two nations?
item.description:
Prime Minister Modi's visit to Poland marks the first time an Indian Prime Minister has travelled to the country in over four decades. The trip is significant given the ongoing geopolitical tensions, particularly in light of the Russia-Ukraine war.
Discussions between Modi and Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk are expected to focus on defense collaboration, trade, and strategic alignment. The visit also offers an opportunity to strengthen ties that had weakened in the post-Cold War era. Poland, a staunch supporter of Ukraine and a key NATO member, presents India with potential for enhanced military cooperation. Modi's visit is anticipated to revitalize the relationship between India and Poland.

item.title: FirstUp: PM Modi to visit Poland, Rahul Gandhi to visit J&K ahead of polls...The headlines today
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will embark on a two-day visit to Poland, the first by an Indian Prime Minister in over 40 years. Discussions are expected to focus on defence cooperation, trade, and strategic partnerships. Modi will also meet with the Indian community and pay tribute at memorials. Meanwhile, Congress leaders Rahul Gandhi and Mallikarjun Kharge will visit Jammu and Kashmir ahead of assembly elections, meeting with local leaders and workers. The Reservation Bachao Sangharsh Samiti has called for a Bharat Bandh to protest a recent Supreme Court ruling on SC/ST reservations. Defence Minister Rajnath Singh will begin a five-day US visit, potentially finalising defence agreements. The 2024 World Robot Conference in Beijing will showcase over 60 types of humanoid robots.

item.title: Who was Aruna Shanbaug mentioned by the Supreme Court during Kolkata rape-murder case hearing?
item.description: The Supreme Court mentioned the 1973 case of Aruna Shanbaug, a nurse who was brutally sexually assaulted at Mumbai's KEM Hospital. The attack left her in a persistent vegetative state for 42 years. The perpetrator was convicted but received a lenient sentence. Shanbaug's case sparked a national debate on euthanasia and highlighted the lack of safety for healthcare professionals, particularly women, who are more susceptible to violence. The case led to the first euthanasia plea in the Supreme Court, which ultimately rejected the request but allowed for passive euthanasia in rare cases. Shanbaug passed away in 2015, her story serving as a reminder of the need for safer workplaces for healthcare workers.

item.title: Why is Switzerland offering Rs 49 lakh to pull ammunition from its lakes?
item.description: Switzerland faces a challenge with thousands of tons of old military munitions disposed of in its lakes between 1918 and 1964. These explosives pose risks of environmental contamination and explosions. In response, the Swiss government launched a competition, offering a prize of 50,000 Swiss francs, to find innovative and safe methods for removing the munitions. The competition seeks to involve academia and industry in finding solutions for this decades-old problem. The issue is significant, with Lake Lucerne alone estimated to contain 3,300 tonnes of munitions, posing substantial environmental and safety concerns.

item.title: Can Taylor Swift sue Donald Trump for sharing AI-generated endorsement? What does the law say?
item.description: Donald Trump used AI-generated images of Taylor Swift to falsely suggest she endorsed him for the 2024 election. Swift has not endorsed any candidate this year and previously opposed Trump in 2020 with strong social media statements against him. Legal experts believe Swift could sue Trump for using her likeness without permission, potentially violating her right of publicity. The NO FAKES Act and the ELVIS Act offer legal avenues for Swift, but the effectiveness of these laws in this specific case is unclear. Some experts suggest that a cease-and-desist letter would be a more practical approach, while others believe a lawsuit might not be worth the cost and effort.

item.title: Excessive screen time can cause ‘digital dementia’. What is this condition?
item.description:
Digital dementia, while not a formally recognized diagnosis, refers to cognitive decline potentially linked to excessive technology use. Studies suggest a correlation between increased screen time and risks of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. Excessive screen time can negatively impact memory, attention span, learning capacity, and mental health. Symptoms may mirror those of traditional dementia, such as short-term memory loss and difficulty focusing.
The constant multitasking and rapid information processing associated with technology overuse may strain cognitive functions. Additionally, blue light emitted from screens can disrupt sleep patterns, further hindering cognitive performance.
Preventing digital dementia involves managing screen time and engaging in activities that challenge cognitive function. Limiting passive media consumption, prioritizing real-world interactions, and incorporating brain-boosting activities like puzzles, reading, and learning new skills can help mitigate the potential risks.

item.title: Fashion faux pas: Why Zara has pulled its ‘perfect snack’ T-shirt off shelves
item.description:
Zara faced backlash for a t-shirt marketed towards girls that read "the perfect snack" and featured a strawberry with the phrase "take a bite".
Mothers on social media criticized the garment, deeming the wording sexually suggestive due to the slang use of "snack" to refer to attractive individuals. Zara subsequently apologized, pulled the shirt from stores and their website, stating their intent was not to imply anything other than the literal meaning of "snack". This incident isn't Zara's first controversy, as the brand has previously faced criticism for advertising campaigns and product designs deemed insensitive or offensive.

item.title: Mpox outbreak: Why has the world reacted so slowly?
item.description:
The current mpox crisis in Congo, which has seen 96% of the world's cases this year, highlights a slow global response to the threat. While the 2022 outbreak primarily affected gay and bisexual men in wealthier countries, the current strain is disproportionately affecting young people in Congo. Despite the availability of vaccines and treatments, Congo lacks access to these resources due to logistical and political challenges, exacerbating the situation.
The spread of the new, potentially more infectious strain raises concerns about its potential to reach other countries. Experts warn that Africa's lack of appropriate assistance during the 2022 outbreak has created this situation. A rapid and coordinated global response is crucial to prevent a wider pandemic.

item.title: In Graphics | How do mosquitoes detect people, spread diseases?
item.description: World Mosquito Day, observed on August 20th, highlights the dangers of mosquito-borne diseases like malaria, dengue fever, Zika virus, and West Nile virus, which claim millions of lives annually. This year's theme emphasizes equitable access to malaria treatment, diagnosis, and prevention. The day commemorates the dedication of individuals and organizations working to combat these diseases.

item.title: How pro-Trump supporters are spreading rumours about Kamala Harris’ ‘drinking problem’
item.description: Following a surge in support for Kamala Harris, some of Donald Trump's supporters have started to spread rumors about her alleged drinking problem. They point to videos of Harris speaking at rallies and events, claiming her speech patterns and demeanor suggest intoxication. These claims have been widely shared on social media, with some users comparing her to "vodka Pelosi" and speculating about the potential dangers of a drunk Commander-in-Chief. Supporters of Harris, however, have dismissed these accusations as baseless and sexist. They argue that the videos do not provide evidence of alcohol consumption and that the attacks are part of a larger pattern of Trump and his allies attempting to discredit her.

item.title: What led to the sinking of the Bayesian superyacht off Italy’s coast?
item.description: The 56-meter superyacht Bayesian sank off the coast of Sicily, Italy, after being caught in a severe storm. The yacht, owned by British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, had 22 people on board. One person died, and six others, including Lynch and his daughter, are still missing. 15 people were rescued. The Italian coastguard believes the Bayesian was struck by strong winds, possibly exacerbated by its tall mast and potentially a raised lifting keel. The tragedy raises concerns about yacht safety in the face of increasingly frequent extreme weather events in the Mediterranean.

item.title: How Islamic preacher Zakir Naik, a fugitive in India, became Malaysia's guest
item.description: Zakir Naik, a controversial Islamic preacher, is the subject of tension between India and Malaysia. Naik fled India in 2016 after being accused of inciting terror and hate speech. He gained notoriety for remarks supporting Osama bin Laden, advocating for the death penalty for homosexuals and apostates, and defending Islamic State practices. While Malaysia granted Naik permanent residency, India has repeatedly sought his extradition, facing rejections from the Malaysian government. Naik himself claims his words have been misconstrued, stating his intention was never to incite violence or hatred. The issue of Naik's status remains a point of contention between the two nations despite attempts to deepen their strategic ties.

item.title: After Hathras, women CBI officials investigate Kolkata rape-murder: Who are they?
item.description:
The CBI is investigating the rape and murder of a junior doctor at Kolkata's RG Kar Medical College. Two experienced officers, Sampat Meena and Seema Pahuja, have been assigned to the case. Meena, an additional director with the CBI, previously led investigations into high-profile cases like the 2020 Hathras rape-murder and the 2017 Unnao rape. Pahuja, an additional superintendent of police, is known for her work in complex cases and successfully resolved the 2017 "Gudiya" case in Himachal Pradesh involving the rape and murder of a student.
Both officers are respected for their sharp investigative skills, dedication to justice, and commitment to protecting women's rights.

item.title: Centre’s U-turn on lateral entry into bureaucracy: How it snowballed into a political row
item.description:
Following significant backlash from opposition parties and some members of the ruling NDA coalition, the Centre has withdrawn its advertisement for lateral entry into the bureaucracy.
The opposition had strongly criticized the scheme for lacking reservation provisions for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Other Backward Classes. Concerns were also raised by NDA allies like the Lok Janshakti Party and the Janata Dal (United) over the lack of reservations.
In response to the criticism, Union Minister Jitendra Singh recommended the cancellation of the advertisement, emphasizing the government's commitment to social justice and the need to review the reservation policy in lateral recruitment.

item.title: From Joe Biden’s exit to Hillary Clinton’s boost to Kamala Harris: Key takeaways from DNC on Day 1
item.description:
The first night of the 2024 Democratic National Convention was marked by President Biden's emotional farewell and the formal transition of power to Vice President Kamala Harris. Biden highlighted his administration's accomplishments while praising Harris's leadership.
Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton delivered a powerful speech, invoking the "glass ceiling" metaphor and expressing hope that Harris will become the first female president. The convention also addressed the ongoing war in Gaza, with Biden acknowledging the concerns of protesters and pledging to work towards peace.
Democrats criticized former President Trump's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and his stance on labor rights, highlighting the personal tragedies caused by the pandemic and celebrating Biden's support for workers.
The night featured tributes to civil rights leader Jesse Jackson, emphasizing the theme of diversity within the party. With Biden stepping back from politics, the convention set the stage for Harris and her running mate, Governor Tim Walz, to lead the Democrats in the 2024 election.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder: CBI to conduct polygraph test of accused. How accurate is it?
item.description: The CBI has been granted permission to conduct a polygraph test on Sanjay Roy, the prime accused in the rape and murder of a trainee doctor in Kolkata. The test, also known as a lie detector test, measures physiological reactions to determine truthfulness. Evidence gathered including CCTV footage and a Bluetooth headset linked to Roy led to his arrest. Roy allegedly confessed to the crime. The High Court has postponed the case hearing until August 29.

item.title: Who is Mike Lynch, UK’s ‘Bill Gates’ missing in superyacht sinking?
item.description:
Mike Lynch, a British tech entrepreneur nicknamed "UK's Bill Gates," was on his superyacht Bayesian when it sank off the coast of Italy, killing one person and leaving several, including Lynch himself, missing.
Lynch rose to prominence as the founder of Autonomy, a successful software company that he sold to Hewlett-Packard for $11 billion in a controversial deal.
Following the sale, Lynch faced legal challenges and accusations of fraud related to the deal's terms. After years of litigation, he was acquitted of all charges in June. He was celebrating this acquittal with friends and family on the Bayesian when the yacht sank due to a sudden storm.

item.title: Top Gear: How Ethiopia has seen a rapid transition to electric vehicles
item.description:
Ethiopia is spearheading a green mobility revolution in Africa by banning gas-powered car imports and promoting electric vehicles (EVs). Driven by abundant hydropower and government incentives, the country has seen a rapid surge in EV adoption, with over 100,000 EVs currently in circulation. Local manufacturing is also gaining momentum, with companies assembling EVs using imported parts.
Despite these advancements, economic constraints and the high cost of EVs pose hurdles to widespread adoption.
The government aims to quadruple EV ownership by 2032 and is investing in electric public transport to make the transition more accessible to all income levels.

item.title: FirstUp: Supreme Court to hear Kolkata rape-murder case, DNC’s Day 2 to see big faces
item.description:
The Supreme Court of India will hear the case of a doctor who was raped and murdered at Kolkata's RG Kar Medical College and Hospital. The apex court will also hear a bail plea from BRS leader K Kavitha in the Delhi excise policy case.
Meanwhile, the notification for the first phase of elections in Jammu and Kashmir will be issued. India and Japan will hold their third 2+2 ministerial dialogue to discuss strategic ties and the Indo-Pacific situation. Former US First Lady Michelle Obama is expected to address the Democratic National Convention.

item.title: PM Modi to visit Ukraine on August 23: What is India's stance on the Russia war?
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will become the first Indian prime minister to visit Ukraine since the establishment of diplomatic relations. The visit, at the invitation of President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, takes place after Modi's recent trips to Russia and Austria. India has maintained a neutral stance on the conflict, advocating for dialogue and diplomacy while not condemning Russia or joining Western sanctions. Modi has repeatedly emphasized that the current era is not one for war, calling for peace talks and a solution acceptable to all parties involved. He has highlighted India's support for peace and its efforts to mitigate the conflict's global impact through engagement with all stakeholders.

item.title: Men, do you claim to be tall on dating apps? How ChatGPT can bust that lie
item.description: Women are using ChatGPT to uncover potential lies about height on dating profiles. They upload pictures of the men to the AI, which estimates their height based on proportions and surroundings. A venture capitalist, Justine Moore, tested ChatGPT on photos of friends and family and found the estimates to be accurate within an inch. This comes as OKCupid analysis shows men are increasingly exaggerating their height on dating apps, potentially motivated by societal preferences for taller men. Dating experts caution against the use of AI for this purpose, emphasizing the importance of treating people with kindness and remembering the human element in online dating.

item.title: How US man makes $1 million from a restaurant that’s never served a customer
item.description:
Drew Talbert, a former server, created a wildly popular fictional restaurant called Bistro Huddy on TikTok. The account features comedic skits about the restaurant industry, garnering nearly 4.5 million followers.
Talbert earns a high six-figure income annually through merchandise sales, Patreon subscriptions, and brand partnerships. His videos resonate with viewers who find them relatable and humorous, often reliving their own restaurant experiences. Talbert, along with his wife, writes, films, and edits videos, utilizing their acting and social media experience. The characters, including Amber the hostess and Nicole the sarcastic blonde waiter, have become fan favorites, contributing to Bistro Huddy's immense success.

item.title: How the Bangladesh crisis has affected tourism in India
item.description:
The political turmoil in Bangladesh has significantly impacted tourism in India. Outbound tourism from Bangladesh has plummeted, with a reported 90% drop in travel due to flight and visa suspensions.
Though medical tourism from Bangladesh continued to grow in 2023, reaching 449,570 patients, experts predict a potential 10-15% decline in 2024.
This instability has noticeably affected key Indian tourism hubs like Kolkata, where hotel occupancy has dropped and local businesses reliant on Bangladeshi tourists are suffering.

item.title: Why thousands of activists are preparing to protest at the Democratic National Convention
item.description:
Around 40,000 protesters are expected to gather in Chicago during the Democratic National Convention, expressing various concerns, primarily an immediate ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas war. Organizers, including the Coalition to March on the DNC, have secured permits for demonstrations and marches near the United Center, the convention's venue.
Protests focus on issues such as US foreign policy, economic justice, reproductive rights, and the role of the Biden administration in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Some groups express discontent with the administration's stance, while others, like the Poor People's Army, advocate for economic equality and highlight the plight of marginalized communities.
Chicago authorities have implemented security measures, including police training, traffic management plans, and emergency preparedness, while also emphasizing the protection of First Amendment rights.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder case: Why doctors in India are in urgent need for a central protection law
item.description:
The recent rape and murder of a trainee doctor in Kolkata has reignited the demand for a central law to protect healthcare workers in India. Instances of violence against doctors in the workplace are widespread, with a study by the Indian Medical Association revealing that over 75% of doctors have faced some form of violence.
Several factors contribute to this issue, including an overburdened public health system, high healthcare costs, and a lack of trust in the healthcare delivery system.
While some states have enacted their own laws, the absence of a national framework has led to inconsistencies and loopholes. Medical professionals are urging the government to create safe zones in healthcare institutions, provide adequate security measures, and ensure that perpetrators are held accountable for their actions.

item.title: Anwar Ibrahim to meet PM Modi: How palm oil has played a role in India-Malaysia ties
item.description:
The relationship between India and Malaysia is significantly influenced by their trade in palm oil. India is the world's largest importer of palm oil, with Malaysia being one of the primary suppliers.
Historically, diplomatic issues led to a reduction in palm oil imports from Malaysia to India. However, the trade relationship has since recovered, with both nations seeking to strengthen cooperation in the palm oil sector.
They are working together to counter global negativity towards palm oil, particularly concerns regarding deforestation. This collaboration aims to ensure the continued growth and sustainability of the palm oil trade between the two countries.

item.title: Democratic National Convention kicks off in Chicago: What to expect
item.description:
The Democratic National Convention (DNC) 2024 kicked off in Chicago, marking a historic moment as Vice President Kamala Harris and Governor Tim Walz were formally nominated. The convention, which runs from August 19th to 22nd, saw President Joe Biden deliver a final address before stepping back from the political stage. The DNC platform highlights ambitious proposals like raising a billionaire income tax, lowering childcare costs, investing in clean energy, and restoring reproductive rights.
Harris, aiming for a broader appeal, is emphasizing her stance as an advocate for everyday Americans and unveiled an economic policy agenda targeting working-class voters. The convention's notable speakers include former Presidents Barack and Bill Clinton, Michelle Obama, and prominent figures like Jacinda Ardern. Anticipation remains high as Harris and Walz embark on their journey towards the November election versus Donald Trump.

item.title: Are there vaccines against mpox? How effective are they?
item.description:
Mpox, formerly known as monkeypox, is a viral infection caused by the monkeypox virus. It spreads through contact with infected individuals, materials, or animals and presents symptoms such as skin lesions, fever, headache, muscle pain, and swollen lymph nodes.
The World Health Organization has declared mpox a global health emergency due to rising cases in Africa, Sweden, Pakistan, and the Philippines. While there isn't a specific vaccine for mpox, vaccines developed for smallpox, such as MVA-BN (Jynneos) and ACAM2000, offer cross-protection as both viruses belong to the Orthopoxvirus genus.
These vaccines are reported to be around 85% effective against mpox, potentially reducing severity or preventing infection altogether.

item.title: Why is a rail strike looming large over Canada? How could it hurt the economy?
item.description:
A potential strike by the Teamsters Canada Rail Conference on August 22, 2024, could severely disrupt Canada's freight rail system. Contract negotiations between the union, representing 9,300 engineers, conductors, and other rail workers, and the two largest railway companies, Canadian National Railway (CN) and Canadian Pacific Kansas City (CPKC), have stalled.
The union accuses the companies of seeking concessions that compromise worker safety, while the companies maintain their offers uphold safety standards and comply with government regulations.
A strike would have significant economic repercussions, impacting supply chains, particularly for agriculture, and potentially causing billions in losses. It could also lead to truck rate increases as freight seeks alternative transport methods.
While the federal government has the power to impose binding arbitration, it has not yet indicated a willingness to intervene, leaving the future of negotiations uncertain.

item.title: After Kolkata, now Bengaluru horror: How hitching a ride led to 21-year-old’s rape
item.description:
In Bengaluru, a 21-year-old college student was sexually assaulted by an unidentified man who offered her a ride home after she reportedly met with an accident while returning from a social gathering. The incident occurred in the early hours of Sunday, August 18, near Hosur Main Road. According to the police, the survivor was intoxicated and the suspect, instead of taking her to her destination, took her to an isolated location and assaulted her. He fled when the survivor's friends arrived at the scene. The survivor is currently in stable condition at a private hospital. Bengaluru police have registered a case and formed five teams to apprehend the suspect.
Police are investigating the incident and are confident of arresting the perpetrator soon.

item.title: Ukraine destroys second bridge in Russia: What is Kyiv’s plan in Kursk?
item.description: Ukraine has intensified its offensive in Russia's Kursk region, destroying two key bridges to disrupt supply lines. President Zelenskyy aims to create a buffer zone within Russia to protect Ukraine from further attacks. The operation has been successful in advancing Ukrainian forces and capturing territory, boosting morale and demonstrating Ukraine's ability to take the initiative. Zelenskyy has called on Western allies to lift restrictions on long-range weapons, enabling strikes deeper into Russian territory. Russia's response has been largely reactive, with limited success in organizing a counteroffensive. The situation has escalated tensions, with Belarus warning of potential nuclear consequences and concerns raised about the safety of the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder case: The many questions parents of the victim are now asking Mamata Banerjee
item.description:
The death of a postgraduate trainee doctor at Kolkata’s RG Kar Medical College has sparked nationwide protests and raised serious questions about women's safety in West Bengal. The victim's parents have accused Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee of suppressing the protests and trying to hush up the case, alleging a double standard in her approach. They claim the police initially tried to pass off the death as a suicide and that the investigation was mishandled.
The primary suspect is a Kolkata Police volunteer who allegedly confessed to the crime. The case is now being investigated by the CBI, which is examining call logs and conversations of key individuals, including the former principal of the hospital. The incident has drawn widespread condemnation, with the victim's mother and other groups calling for justice and the resignation of Chief Minister Banerjee.

item.title: Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim to visit India: What are the ties that the two countries share?
item.description:
Malaysia and India established diplomatic relations in 1957, with ties strengthened over the years through numerous high-level visits. The two nations elevated their relationship to an Enhanced Strategic Partnership in 2015. Malaysia is home to the third-largest Indian diaspora globally.
Trade between the countries has been steadily increasing, reaching $20 billion in 2022-23, and is expected to grow further.
Defense cooperation is also a focus, with recent joint exercises and an amendment to the 1993 defense cooperation MoU.
Tourism is another important dimension, with Malaysia offering visa-free travel to Indians.
Despite some challenges related to past political statements and the extradition request for Zakir Naik, experts believe Anwar Ibrahim’s visit will contribute to strengthening ties between the two countries.

item.title: FirstUp: US Democratic National Convention, Malaysia PM’s visit to India… Headlines today
item.description:
Today marks the beginning of the 2024 Democratic National Convention in Chicago, where Kamala Harris will be formally nominated as the party's presidential candidate. Concurrent with the convention, Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is on a two-day visit to India, focusing on strengthening ties and potentially signing agreements, including one on Indian worker recruitment.
The event comes on the backdrop of India celebrating Rakshabandhan, a festival celebrating the bond between siblings. Other notable occurrences include the conclusion of the 50-day Amarnath Yatra pilgrimage, as well as ongoing talks between India and Australia regarding a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement.

item.title: Is it safe for children to lift weights? Does it stunt growth?
item.description:
Exercise is important for children's physical and mental health. Resistance training, which includes weightlifting, is safe for kids as long as proper precautions are taken. Studies show no evidence that resistance training stunts growth.
On the contrary, it improves strength, power, speed, agility, and endurance. It can also benefit children who struggle with aerobic activities. Children should get at least 60 minutes of physical activity daily, which can include resistance training three days a week.
It's important to start slowly and make it fun. As children get older, they can progress to more targeted training and heavier weights. Supervise children, start with lighter weights, and encourage proper technique.

item.title: Mpox outbreak declared a public health emergency: How to prevent it from becoming a global pandemic
item.description:
The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention has declared the mpox outbreak sweeping across Africa a continental public health emergency. This comes after a virulent strain of the disease spread rapidly to 16 countries with six new countries being affected in just 10 days.
There have been over 15,000 confirmed cases since the start of 2024. Compared to previous years, this clade II strain, much less dangerous, has a 0.1% fatality rate, while the newly prevalent clade I strain has a 3-4% fatality rate, posing a more serious threat, particularly affecting children.
Experts are concerned about the virus's rapid mutation and spread, exacerbated by a long incubation period and vague initial symptoms, making containment difficult. The shortage of vaccines is a major obstacle, as demand greatly exceeds available supply.
Key measures to control the outbreak include widespread testing, community education focusing on broader transmission routes, and accelerated development and distribution of vaccines. Urgent action is needed to prevent this epidemic from escalating into a global pandemic.

item.title: Why extreme weather in Pakistan has given rise to 'monsoon brides'
item.description: Since the devastating floods of 2022 in Pakistan, a concerning trend has emerged: "monsoon brides." Families in rural Sindh, struggling to recover from the floods' economic impact, are marrying off their young daughters to escape poverty. These marriages often involve men significantly older than the girls. While the families believe they are securing a better future for their daughters, the reality is often harsh. The girls experience limited opportunities and face difficult circumstances, with many returning to live with their parents due to their husbands' unemployment. This trend underscores the vulnerability of young girls in the face of climate-related disasters and the urgent need for sustainable solutions to address poverty and empower women.

item.title: This Week in Explainers: Why mpox is now a global health emergency
item.description:
The WHO declared mpox a global health emergency, highlighting the spread of the virus beyond its African origins, with cases now reported in Sweden and Pakistan.
In a stunning move, Ukrainian forces launched a significant incursion into Russian territory, seizing control of dozens of settlements in the Kursk region. This bold counteroffensive has exposed vulnerabilities in Russia's defenses and prompted a warning from President Putin.
Thailand appointed Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, as its youngest prime minister following the removal of the previous leader.
Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced his resignation, paving the way for a new leader to take over the ruling party. This decision comes amidst economic challenges and security concerns in the region.

item.title: IMA doctors' 24-hour-long nationwide strike: What are their 5 demands?
item.description: Doctors across India are on strike, protesting the rape and murder of a junior doctor in Kolkata. This strike has disrupted all non-emergency medical services nationwide. The Indian Medical Association (IMA) has made five key demands to the government, focusing on the safety of medical professionals. These demands include a central law to address violence against healthcare workers, improved working and living conditions for resident doctors, enhanced hospital security, fair compensation for the victim's family, and a thorough investigation into the crime and vandalism at RG Kar Hospital. The IMA argues for stronger protections and action to prevent such tragedies in the future. The Union Health Ministry has held a meeting with doctor representatives, acknowledging their concerns and assuring them of efforts to enhance healthcare worker safety. The ministry has also requested doctors to resume duties in light of rising dengue and malaria cases.

item.title: Who is Tahawwur Rana, the 26/11 Mumbai attacks accused, who can now be extradited to India from the US?
item.description:
A US court has ruled that Tahawwur Rana is eligible for extradition to India to face trial for his role in the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks. The court rejected Rana's appeal based on insufficient evidence and the "non bis in idem" (double jeopardy) clause.
Rana, a Pakistani-Canadian businessman, was convicted in the US for his involvement in the 2008 Mumbai attacks and for supporting a plot to attack a Danish newspaper. According to US authorities, he aided his childhood friend David Headley, a key figure in the Mumbai attacks, by providing him with a cover story and financial support for his surveillance activities in India.
India has been seeking Rana's extradition since 2019, and the Biden administration has supported the request. Rana still has the option to appeal the decision.

item.title: Is India prepared for mpox after it being declared a global health emergency?
item.description:
India is strengthening its preparedness against mpox following the WHO's global health emergency declaration.
The country has already witnessed a small number of cases in 2022, primarily from travelers and local transmissions.
High-level meetings are underway with government agencies and health institutions to review the situation and reinforce precautionary measures. Airports and seaports are being advised to remain vigilant for potential cases.
While India hasn't reported new cases recently, experts recognize the need for continued vigilance. Existing smallpox and chickenpox vaccines are believed to offer some protection against mpox.
The ICMR is actively conducting serosurveys to assess exposure levels and pharmaceutical companies are working on developing a dedicated mpox vaccine.

item.title: Sunita Williams, Barry Wilmore stuck in space: How six months in space alters one’s perception of time
item.description:
Two NASA astronauts, Commander Barry Wilmore and pilot Sunita Williams, are currently stranded on the International Space Station (ISS) awaiting a return trip to Earth. Their original spacecraft, the Boeing Starliner, experienced technical difficulties, leaving their return date uncertain.
Nasa and Boeing are assessing the Starliner's safety, and a decision could be made soon. If deemed safe, their stay may be short. If not, they face a potential six-month wait. Research suggests that waiting can be psychologically challenging, distorting our perception of time and increasing stress. Being busy and having clear information about the situation can help manage the waiting period. Interestingly, studies on people in Antarctica show that constant activity can make time feel like it passes quickly. This might offer hope for the stranded astronauts.

item.title: This Week in Explainers: What happened in the Kolkata rape case that led to doctors’ protests in India?
item.description:
This week in India, the horrific rape and murder of a junior doctor in Kolkata sparked outrage and nationwide protests. The incident also ignited a political battle between the TMC, BJP, and CPI(M) in West Bengal.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed the nation on Independence Day, emphasizing the need for swift justice in crimes against women. He also highlighted the progress of India's space sector, which was further showcased with the successful launch of the EOS-08 satellite.
Controversy arose when US-based firm Hindenburg accused Sebi chief Madhabi Puri Buch of a conflict of interest related to Adani Group due to past investments by her husband. Meanwhile, India's Olympic medalists were welcomed back with celebrations and financial rewards. However, the placement season for MBA graduates from top institutes like IIMs saw a slowdown.

item.title: Jammu and Kashmir to hold polls after a decade. What happened in the last elections?
item.description:
The Election Commission of India has announced that Assembly elections in Jammu and Kashmir will be held in three phases, starting September 18th and culminating on October 1st. This is the first election in the Union Territory since 2014, after a Supreme Court order mandated polls by September 30, 2024. The court also ordered the restoration of statehood.
The 2014 elections saw the PDP emerge as the single largest party. Following the BJP's withdrawal of support from the PDP-led government in 2018, Governor's Rule was imposed. In 2019, Jammu and Kashmir's special status was revoked and the state was bifurcated into two Union Territories.

item.title: US records 300,000 child marriages from 2000: Why is it still legal?
item.description: Child marriage remains legal in 37 US states despite global efforts to eradicate it. Over 300,000 children have been married in the US since 2000, with girls most often targeted. Legal exceptions like parental consent and judicial approval allow the practice to persist, even in states that have banned child marriage outright. This legal loophole makes it difficult for child brides to escape abusive relationships. Child marriage has severe consequences for victims, including increased risk of poverty, dropping out of school, and experiencing domestic and sexual violence. Despite growing momentum to ban child marriage nationwide, opposition from various groups continues to hinder progress. Advocates argue that a uniform federal law setting a minimum age for marriage is essential to protect minors.

item.title: What is ‘slapped cheek virus’, the contagious disease on the rise in the US?
item.description: Parvovirus B19, commonly known as “fifth disease,” is currently experiencing a surge in cases across the US. The virus is known for its distinctive "slapped-cheek" rash, and although it mostly causes mild illness, it poses a risk to pregnant individuals and those with blood disorders. The CDC reports that around 10% of the US population and 40% of children aged 5-9 have recently shown evidence of infection. While most people recover without complications, pregnant women infected with the virus may face risks to their fetus, and individuals with weakened immune systems or blood disorders are at risk for severe complications like anemia. The virus spreads through respiratory droplets, and prevention focuses on handwashing, avoiding close contact with the sick, and for high-risk groups, wearing masks.

item.title: Double whammy for Indian graduates: How IIMs are hiking fees but first pay drops
item.description:
The 2024 batch of graduates from India's leading business schools are facing a challenging job market with stagnant median salaries. Several IIMs, including Kozhikode, Indore, and Lucknow, have reported drops in median pay compared to previous years.
While IIM Ahmedabad's figures are yet to be released, it still hasn't reached the levels seen in 2023. Despite a slow placement season, marked by a reduction in offers from consulting firms, several IIMs, including Kolkata, Ahmedabad, Lucknow, and Bangalore, managed to achieve 100% placement rates by the final phase.
However, the overall median salaries remain lower compared to previous years.
Adding to the financial burden, students are experiencing increased fees at various IIMs, with institutions citing rising operational costs as the reason. This combination of stagnant salaries and increasing fees is putting a financial strain on IIM students.

item.title: Where did the asteroid that wiped out dinosaurs come from? We have the answer
item.description: A new study sheds light on the origin of the asteroid that ended the reign of the dinosaurs 66 million years ago. Researchers analyzed sediment samples and ruthenium isotopes, revealing that the asteroid was a C-type, carbonaceous asteroid that formed beyond Jupiter's orbit. This finding refutes earlier theories suggesting a cometary origin and highlights the rare nature of such impacts. The study's findings could be crucial in understanding Earth's water origins and in assessing future asteroid threats.

item.title: 1 in 4 MBBS students suffer from mental disorders in India: What NMC’s ‘worrying’ survey on medicos reveal
item.description: A recent survey by India's National Medical Commission revealed alarming statistics about the mental health of medical students. The survey found that 27.8% of undergraduate students and 31.23% of postgraduate students reported experiencing suicidal thoughts. Factors contributing to these issues include a lack of access to mental health services, stigma surrounding mental health, stressful working conditions, and financial instability. The survey also highlighted concerns about inadequate living conditions, faculty support, and the rural service bond policy. The report calls for immediate action, recommending measures such as providing 24/7 mental health support, improving living conditions, reducing working hours, standardizing pay scales, and establishing mentor-mentee programs.

item.title: Who is Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Thailand's youngest PM? What challenges lie ahead of her?
item.description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, known as Ung Ing, is Thailand's youngest prime minister and the fourth member of her family to hold the position. Daughter of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, Paetongtarn entered politics in 2021 and was elected leader of the Pheu Thai Party last year. She faces challenges including a struggling economy, the declining popularity of her party, and navigating the influence of her father, who remains a powerful force in Thai politics. Paetongtarn's recent appointment follows the ousting of former Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin and the dissolution of the Move Forward Party, highlighting the political turmoil in Thailand.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder: How RG Kar incident has spurred a political blame game in Bengal
item.description:
A young trainee doctor's rape and murder in Kolkata has triggered a political blame game in West Bengal. The ruling Trinamool Congress (TMC) blames the opposition BJP and CPI(M) for inciting violence at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital where the incident occurred. Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee claims the vandalism was carried out by "outsiders" and accuses the opposition of attempting to defame Bengal. She further alleges a coordinated effort to politicize the issue and draw comparisons to Bangladesh.
The opposition parties, however, criticize the TMC government's handling of the case, demanding Banerjee's resignation and questioning the alleged cover-up. The BJP accuses TMC goons of being behind the vandalism and calls for deployment of central forces at the hospital. The CPI(M) and CPI also condemn the violence and blame the TMC government for the unsafe environment for doctors .
As protests erupt in Bengal, Banerjee plans to lead a rally demanding the death penalty for the accused while opposition parties hold their own demonstrations over the incident.

item.title: From Africa to Sweden and now Pakistan, how mpox is spreading across the globe
item.description:
Mpox, a viral infection related to smallpox, has been declared a global health emergency by the WHO. The current outbreak is the worst ever in Africa, with over 27,000 cases and 1,100 deaths since January 2023. A new, more easily transmissible variant, clade Ib, is driving the spread, particularly in central and west Africa.
Symptoms include fever, headaches, muscle aches, and a characteristic rash that can progress to pustules and scabs. While usually mild, mpox can be fatal in some cases.
The WHO is concerned about the virus spreading beyond Africa, with cases recently reported in Sweden and Pakistan. There is no vaccine specifically for mpox, although the smallpox vaccine is licensed for use in severe cases. Current efforts are focused on controlling the outbreak in Africa through vaccination, isolation, and public health measures.

item.title: How UK’s Challenger 2 tanks are helping Ukraine in Kursk incursion
item.description: British Challenger 2 tanks have been deployed in Ukraine's cross-border raid into Russia's Kursk Oblast. This marks a significant escalation in the conflict, showcasing Ukraine's growing military capabilities. While the tanks are known for their durability and firepower, they face challenges in Ukraine's terrain and logistical constraints. Their heavyweight and dated design limit mobility, and their unique ammunition type presents logistical hurdles. Reports suggest only a handful remain operational, with concerns about repair delays and low readiness levels. Despite these challenges, the deployment holds symbolic and tactical value, demonstrating Ukraine's offensive capabilities and potentially impacting the psychological warfare aspect of the conflict.

item.title: Matthew Perry’s death: Who is the ‘Ketamine Queen’ charged in FRIENDS star’s demise?
item.description: The death of Matthew Perry, star of the sitcom "Friends," has led to a criminal investigation uncovering a network involved in drug distribution and exploitation. Perry's assistant, two doctors, and a drug dealer known as the "Ketamine Queen" have been charged. Authorities allege that these individuals conspired to supply Perry with ketamine, a powerful anesthetic, contributing to his death. The investigation revealed that Perry's fight with addiction led him to seek ketamine treatment, but when his doctors refused to increase his dosage, he turned to illegal sources. The "Ketamine Queen", Jasveen Sangha, is accused of being the primary supplier, and faces the most serious charges, including conspiracy to distribute ketamine and maintaining a drug-involved premises. Perry's death has sparked a wider investigation into the illegal ketamine trade and the individuals who profit from it.

item.title: Isro successfully launches SSLV-D3: Why is this mission significant for India’s space sector?
item.description:
India's space agency, ISRO, successfully launched the third developmental flight of its Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV) on August 16, 2023. This mission, designated SSLV-D3, carried the 175-kilogram Earth Observation Satellite-8 (EOS-08) into Low Earth Orbit. The SSLV is a three-stage rocket designed for commercial use, capable of launching satellites weighing up to 500 kilograms into orbit. This successful launch marks the completion of the SSLV development project by ISRO.
The EOS-08 satellite is equipped with advanced instruments, including an Electro Optical Infrared Payload (EOIR), for Earth monitoring, disaster management, and support for the Gaganyaan mission. The launch signifies a significant step in ISRO's strategy to commercialize space launch services and meet the growing demand for small satellite launches.

item.title: Can ousted PM Sheikh Hasina be extradited from India to Bangladesh?
item.description:
Bangladesh's interim government is considering requesting India's extradition of former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, who fled the country amid protests and now faces multiple accusations, including murder and enforced disappearance. Bangladesh and India have an extradition treaty since 2013, allowing the exchange of convicts or undertrials. However, the treaty's applicability to Hasina's case is debated, as it may not cover political asylum seekers.
India is in a delicate position, balancing its long-standing ties with Hasina and the need to maintain good relations with the current Bangladesh administration. Extradition could strain ties with Bangladesh and potentially fuel anti-India sentiment.

item.title: FirstUp: ISRO’s SSLV to launch satellite, BJP’s rally in Bengal... Big news today
item.description: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is set to launch its EOS-08 earth observation satellite on the third developmental flight of its Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV). The 175-kg satellite will carry three instruments for various applications including surveillance, disaster monitoring, and UV radiation monitoring. The BJP's women's wing will stage a candlelight march to West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee's residence to protest against violence at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital. Former Delhi Deputy Chief Minister Manish Sisodia will commence his 'padyatra' from Friday, coinciding with Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal's birthday.

item.title: Equipment damaged, stones pelted at police: Inside the violence at RG Kar hospital
item.description: Violence erupted at Kolkata's RG Kar Medical College and Hospital after the tragic rape and murder of a 31-year-old junior doctor. A mob of approximately 40 people, posing as protesters, vandalized the emergency building's ground floor, damaging property, equipment, and even breaking open safes containing medicines.
