The attack came amid nationwide protests demanding justice for the slain doctor. While police fired tear gas to disperse the mob, some officers sustained injuries. The Kolkata Police arrested nine individuals and defended its handling of the situation, blaming a malicious media campaign for inciting violence. The Indian Medical Association condemned the vandalism and expressed its dismay at the Bengal government's handling of the situation, while the BJP accused the TMC of orchestrating the attack.

item.title: Paetongtarn Shinawatra: The 37-year-old political heir set to become Thailand’s prime minister
item.description:
Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, has been nominated as Pheu Thai party's candidate for prime minister. The 37-year-old's nomination comes after the dismissal of the previous Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin.
Paetongtarn, who has a background in business and politics, was one of three prime ministerial candidates from Pheu Thai in last year's election. She was popular among voters and is seen as a strong contender. With her party holding a majority in parliament, she is expected to be approved as the next prime minister, becoming Thailand's second female and youngest leader.

item.title: Quicksplained: What is the famous Leheriya print turban donned by PM Modi for I-Day address?
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressed the nation from the Red Fort on India's 78th Independence Day. He spoke about national development and the theme of "Viksit Bharat 2047." A highlight of the event was Modi wearing a multi-coloured Leheriya print turban, a traditional Rajasthani textile with distinctive wavy patterns. This craft, employing a tie-dye technique, emerged in the 17th century and was originally patronized by the royal courts.
Leheriya, signifying prosperity, has become a symbol of Rajasthani culture and is worn during festivals and special occasions. Modi's choice of attire reflects his appreciation for Indian heritage and craftsmanship.

item.title: Who is Oleksandr Syrski, Ukraine’s ‘butcher’, in-charge of the Kursk incursion in Russia?
item.description:
Ukraine has launched a surprise incursion into Russia's Kursk region, capturing over 1,000 square kilometers of territory and 74 towns and settlements.
The operation, orchestrated by Ukraine's top military commander Oleksandr Syrskyi, marks the deepest Ukrainian penetration into Russia since the start of the full-scale invasion in 2022.
Syrskyi, nicknamed "the butcher," is a veteran commander with extensive battlefield experience who led the defense of Kyiv and the successful counteroffensive in Kharkiv in 2022.
President Zelenskyy has stated that Ukraine's strategic goals are being achieved in the Kursk region, but emphasized that Kyiv does not intend to hold onto the captured territory and offered to cease raids in exchange for a "just peace" from Russia.
Russia has condemned the incursion as an act of aggression and vowed a "tough response." While redeploying troops to the Kursk region, Moscow is unlikely to significantly divert forces from its eastern front lines. The incursion has been seen as a symbolic blow to President Putin, highlighting vulnerabilities in Russian defenses and challenging his narrative of strength.

item.title: Women’s safety, ‘Secular Civil Code’ & more: Key takeaways from PM Modi’s I-Day speech
item.description:
PM Modi, in his 11th consecutive Independence Day speech, outlined his vision for a developed India by 2047, termed "Viksit Bharat 2047." He emphasized the need for a "secular civil code" and called for "one nation, one election" to streamline the political process.
Addressing the recent incidents of violence against women, Modi stressed the need for strict punishment for perpetrators and ensuring women's safety. He highlighted major reforms undertaken by his government, including banking and space sector changes, stating they are aimed at strengthening the country's foundation.
Modi also expressed concern over the safety of Hindu minorities in Bangladesh, calling for peace and happiness in the neighboring country. His speech reiterated his government's zero-tolerance policy towards corruption, pledging to continue the fight against it.

item.title: How women’s security and advancement was a key theme in Modi’s I-Day speech
item.description:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Independence Day speech highlighted the safety and empowerment of women. He acknowledged the public outrage over recent atrocities against women and stressed the need for swift investigations and strict punishment for perpetrators. Modi emphasized the importance of instilling a fear of consequences for such crimes. He also pointed to government initiatives aimed at empowering women, such as the expansion of maternity leave and support for self-help groups.
Modi mentioned the Uniform Civil Code, advocating for a secular and non-discriminatory code to promote gender equality. He emphasized the government's commitment to creating a society where women are respected, supported, and empowered.

item.title: PM Modi honours Birsa Munda in his I-Day speech: Who was the tribal leader?
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, during his 11th Independence Day address, paid tribute to Birsa Munda, a prominent tribal leader who fought for justice and tribal rights. Modi highlighted Munda's influence on the community, his rebellion against British rule, and his vision for a more equitable society. He emphasized Munda's enduring inspiration, particularly in light of his 150th birth anniversary approaching. Munda's legacy is celebrated for his leadership in mobilizing tribals, resisting forced conversions, and advocating for their land rights, ultimately sacrificing his life for his cause at the young age of 25.

item.title: PM Modi delivers 11th I-Day speech: Who holds record for most August 15 addresses?
item.description:
Narendra Modi delivered his 11th Independence Day speech from the Red Fort, equaling a record held by Jawaharlal Nehru and Indira Gandhi. In his speech, Modi praised the nation's progress and acknowledged recent calamities, offering comfort to affected families. He emphasized the importance of unity and hard work in achieving India's goal of becoming a prosperous and developed nation by 2047. Modi's speeches have increased in length, with his first in 2014 lasting 65 minutes and the longest being 94 minutes in 2016.
Nehru delivered 17 consecutive Independence Day speeches, starting in 1947 with his famous "Tryst with Destiny" address. Indira Gandhi delivered 16 speeches, with 11 being consecutive. The average duration of Independence Day speeches has increased over time.

item.title: Who was Bismillah Khan, who gave Independent India its first tune at Delhi's Red Fort?
item.description: Ustad Bismillah Khan, born Qamaruddin Khan in 1916, is renowned for popularizing the shehnai, introducing it from traditional Indian weddings to concert halls. He began learning the instrument at a young age from his uncle in Varanasi and gained recognition after a performance at the All India Music Conference in 1937. His career spanned decades, performing internationally and gracing prestigious global events. He played a significant role in Indian classical music, composing new ragas and captivating audiences with his talent. Khan's contribution to India's independence was monumental, as he was the only musician to perform on the first Independence Day at the Red Fort, a privilege he held for several years. He received numerous accolades, including the Bharat Ratna, India's highest civilian honor, in 2001. Khan's legacy continues to inspire generations of musicians.

item.title: FirstUp: India celebrates Independence Day, Gaza ceasefire talks to resume...The big news today
item.description:
India will celebrate its 78th Independence Day with Prime Minister Narendra Modi addressing the nation from the Red Fort. This year's theme, 'Viksit Bharat @ 2047,' emphasizes India's vision for development by 2047. The event will include the Indian Olympic contingent and guests representing various fields.
Meanwhile, Israel and Hamas will restart ceasefire negotiations, with Qatar, Egypt, and the United States proposing a "final bridge proposal." This three-phase plan involves Israel withdrawing from Gaza, the release of hostages, and a reconstruction plan.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas will address the Turkish parliament, emphasizing Israel's actions in Palestinian territories and seeking global support for Palestine.
Finally, Andhra Pradesh will reopen 100 Anna Canteens, offering subsidized meals at ₹15 per meal.

item.title: Iranian mother left paralysed under waist after being shot by morality police. Here’s what we know
item.description: Arezoo Badri, a 31-year-old mother of two from Iran, was shot and paralyzed by morality police after failing to stop her car when flagged for allegedly violating the country's hijab law. Badri was driving home with her sister when police ordered her to stop. She was shot in the back despite her compliance according to sources. A source reported that the bullet severely damaged her spinal cord, and doctors are unsure if she will regain the ability to walk. Authorities have kept Badri's condition closely guarded, restricting visitors and barring any photos or videos of her.

item.title: How India celebrated its first Independence Day 77 years ago
item.description:
India celebrated its 78th Independence Day on August 15th. The nation gained freedom from British rule in 1947 after a long struggle led by figures like Mahatma Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru.
August 15, 1947, saw a momentous occasion with Nehru delivering his famous "Tryst with Destiny" speech in the Constituent Assembly. Thousands gathered in Delhi, marking the day with national pride and celebrations. Despite the joy, Gandhi was in Calcutta, working to quell communal tension arising from the partition. India's first Independence Day was a blend of hopeful beginnings and the sobering realities of a newly independent nation grappling with the aftermath of partition.

item.title: Independence Day 2024: Why PM Modi did away with tradition of bullet-proof glass for Red Fort speech
item.description: The tradition of prime ministers addressing the nation on Independence Day from behind bulletproof glass began after Indira Gandhi's assassination in 1984. This security measure continued for three decades, with each PM using varying degrees of protection. In 2014, Narendra Modi broke with this tradition, choosing to deliver his speech without any physical barriers. He felt that Independence Day was a people's festival and wanted a direct connection with his audience. This decision, made despite intelligence warnings, was met with surprise and concern from security officials who had to ramp up security measures extensively.

item.title: Who is Alexei Dyumin, Putin's ex-bodyguard, tapped to turn the tide against Ukraine's incursion in Kursk?
item.description: In response to Ukraine's incursion into the Kursk region, President Putin has appointed Alexei Dyumin, a longtime confidant and former bodyguard, to lead the Russian response. Dyumin, known for his loyalty and military expertise, has a history in Russia's security services and intelligence agencies, including a key role in the annexation of Crimea. Ukrainian forces have seized control of a significant portion of Kursk, forcing thousands of residents to flee. Putin sees Dyumin as the right person to address this significant challenge on Russian soil, and his appointment has been met with approval from pro-Kremlin circles. The operation to expel Ukrainian forces is ongoing.

item.title: Kolkata rape-murder: Was the trainee doctor gang-raped at RG Kar Medical College?
item.description:
The post-mortem report of a deceased trainee doctor revealed a significant amount of semen in her body, strongly suggesting gang rape.
The report, submitted to the Calcutta High Court, also detailed severe injuries, including strangulation marks, genital torture, bite marks, broken bones, and signs of a struggle. The victim's family stated that the body was discovered in a horrifying state, with injuries indicating a brutal and violent attack. The case has been transferred to the CBI, with the accused currently in custody. The high court criticized the hospital management, particularly the former principal, for their failure to report the death promptly and questioned the swift appointment of the former principal to another medical college. The incident has sparked nationwide outrage and protests from medical professionals.

item.title: How Tamil Nadu’s M Karunanidhi championed rights of CMs to hoist Tricolour on I-Day
item.description:
India is celebrating its 78th Independence Day, marking the country's freedom from British rule in 1947.
While the Prime Minister hoists the flag at the Red Fort, the right for Chief Ministers to do the same in their states was granted in 1974. This was due to the efforts of DMK leader M Karunanidhi who, in a battle for state autonomy, argued that elected Chief Ministers should have the same privilege as the Prime Minister.
Karunanidhi's persistent campaigning, including letters to then-Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, led to the government's acceptance of his suggestion. As a result, Karunanidhi became the first Tamil Nadu Chief Minister to unfurl the national flag at Fort St. George on Independence Day, 1974. This change was significant as it reinforced the autonomy of states within India's federal structure.Karunanidhi, known for his strong advocacy for Dravidian rights, viewed this as a step towards respecting state identities within a united India.

item.title: Thai court removes PM Srettha Thavisin over ethics breach. What happens next?
item.description:
Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has been removed from office by the Constitutional Court for an ethics violation. The court ruled that Srettha's appointment of a Cabinet member with a past conviction for bribery was dishonest. Though the former minister had served his sentence, the court found that Srettha, as prime minister, bore responsibility for vetting nominations and had breached ethical standards.
Srettha had maintained that his appointment was legitimate and that he couldn't have anticipated this ruling. His removal comes after a tumultuous period in Thai politics, which has seen the dissolving of the progressive Move Forward Party and numerous challenges to the Pheu Thai party.
Thailand's parliament will now convene to choose a new prime minister from a pre-submitted list of candidates. Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of the influential Thaksin Shinawatra, is seen as a strong contender. The decision brings further uncertainty to a country grappling with economic challenges and political instability.

item.title: How much do Olympic medallists earn? Are their winnings exempted from tax?
item.description:
The article discusses how various countries reward their Olympic medalists with financial bonuses. It highlights India, where cash prizes are tax-free, and the US, which exempted Olympic winnings from taxes after 2016.
Other countries mentioned include Hong Kong and Singapore, which offer the highest payouts, as well as France, Brazil, Canada and Pakistan, each with their own policies regarding tax exemptions for Olympic winnings.
The article also mentions unique rewards given to athletes beyond cash, such as cars, apartments, and even cows.

item.title: Iran promised a 'harsh punishment' against Israel: What is behind the delayed attack?
item.description: Iran has vowed revenge for the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr, sparking tensions in West Asia. However, Tehran has yet to respond, likely due to strategic considerations. Iran's new government is balancing displays of strength with diplomatic and economic factors, and officials are wary of a major conflict. Experts suggest Iran might aim for a symbolic or limited strike to deter further aggression while maintaining the option for future negotiations. The international community, particularly the US, is closely monitoring the situation with fears of escalation, urging Iran to de-escalate and deploying additional military assets to the region.

item.title: Independence Day 2024: Why India’s diaspora is its big gift to the developed world
item.description:
There are a vast number of Indians living abroad, making up the largest diaspora globally. Indian immigrants and their descendants have significantly impacted the United States, Canada, UK, and Australia, particularly in the fields of technology, business, and healthcare.
They hold high positions in Fortune 500 companies, contribute heavily to the innovation sector, and own a substantial proportion of businesses. Indian Diaspora members also excel in academics, with high graduation rates and significant contributions to scientific research.
Politically, individuals of Indian origin are gaining prominence, with high-profile figures serving in government and impacting public perception of India. Their economic success and influence are seen as a driving force for Indian soft power and a testament to the country's growing global stature.

item.title: Why Starbucks fired Indian-origin CEO Laxman Narasimhan months after appointment
item.description: Starbucks abruptly replaced CEO Laxman Narasimhan after just 18 months. The company cited the need for change and future growth. Narasimhan, who came to Starbucks after leading PepsiCo and Reckitt, faced challenges including declining sales, market difficulties, and controversies related to labor issues and the Israel-Palestine conflict. Brian Niccol, CEO of Chipotle, will take over as CEO in September, with Starbucks CFO Rachel Ruggeri serving as interim CEO until then.

item.title: Kolkata rape & murder: How Dr Sandip Ghosh, the ex-principal of RG Kar Medical College, keeps getting hired
item.description:
The murder of a 31-year-old trainee doctor at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital in Kolkata has sparked outrage and scrutiny over the handling of the case by Dr Sandip Ghosh, the former principal.
Dr Ghosh, facing allegations of mismanagement and attempting to downplay the incident as suicide, initially resisted calls for his resignation. After public pressure mounted, he resigned, but the West Bengal government swiftly reinstated and transferred him to another medical college. This move has been met with more protests and criticism, leading the Calcutta High Court to order a CBI investigation and Dr Ghosh to go on leave. The court also questioned the government's decision to reinstate him, calling it "difficult to comprehend."

item.title: SWAT teams, AI-powered systems & more: What goes into securing New Delhi for Independence Day?
item.description:
New Delhi is under heightened security as the nation prepares for the 78th Independence Day celebrations. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will address the nation from the Red Fort. Over 10,000 police personnel, including snipers, SWAT commandos, and sharpshooters, have been deployed across the city. Additional forces are stationed at key locations like airports, railway stations, and markets.
The security perimeter around the Red Fort has been designated as a "no kite flying zone," and advanced AI-powered security systems, including CCTV cameras with facial and number plate recognition, have been installed for enhanced surveillance. A two-step frisking process is in place at Delhi Metro stations. Traffic restrictions and diversions are also in effect.
Following reports of potential threats from anti-India elements, security agencies are on high alert. The Delhi Police recently apprehended a suspect linked to the ISIS Pune module, who was believed to be involved in reconnaissance for potential attacks on VIPs in the Delhi-NCR area.

item.title: What are MQ-9B drones that India is pushing to buy from US? How soon before New Delhi gets them?
item.description:
India is rapidly pushing forward with a deal to acquire 31 MQ-9B drones from the US, aiming to finalize the agreement by November or December. The drones, manufactured by General Atomics, will bolster India's military capabilities at a time of heightened tensions with neighbors China and Pakistan. The deal includes 15 SeaGuardians for the Navy and eight SkyGuardians each for the Army and Air Force.
The MQ-9B, also known as the "hunter-killer" drone, is a sophisticated unmanned aerial vehicle capable of long-endurance surveillance, carrying various weapons, and operating in harsh weather conditions. Its acquisition is seen as a significant step in enhancing India's intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities, particularly in the Indian Ocean Region and along its land borders.

item.title: A rape every 16 minutes: The shocking numbers on crimes against women in India
item.description: The murder of a 31-year-old junior doctor at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital in Kolkata has sparked widespread protests and demands for justice. The victim was found in the hospital's seminar hall and preliminary autopsy results suggest sexual assault and murder. Sanjoy Roy, arrested based on CCTV footage, is the prime suspect. The case has been handed over to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) due to public outcry. This incident highlights the alarming rise in crimes against women in India, with the NCRB reporting 4,45,256 cases in 2022, averaging 51 reports each hour.

item.title: Will a new round of Israel-Hamas ceasefire talks culminate in a deal?
item.description:
International mediators are attempting to restart ceasefire negotiations between Israel and Hamas to end the 10-month conflict and secure the release of hostages.
Despite a proposed three-phase plan backed by the US, key issues remain unresolved. Israel is concerned about the duration of the initial ceasefire and Hamas' potential stalling tactics. Hamas fears Israel might resume hostilities after releasing vulnerable hostages and is wary of additional Israeli demands.
The assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and a top Hezbollah commander further complicates the situation, escalating regional tensions and diverting attention from ceasefire efforts. Both Netanyahu and Hamas' new leader, Yahya Sinwar, face political pressures that could impede negotiations.

item.title: I-Day controversy: Why AAP's Kailash Gahlot not Atishi will hoist the flag in Delhi
item.description:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal, currently in jail, proposed that his Education Minister, Atishi, hoist the national flag at the Independence Day event. However, the General Administration Department deemed this decision legally invalid, stating that Kejriwal cannot authorize someone else to do so in his place. The department cited prison rules and said the CM's communication was an abuse of privileges.
Lt Governor VK Saxena then nominated Delhi Home Minister Kailash Gahlot to hoist the flag, which has heightened tensions between the AAP and the LG. The AAP views this as an attempt to undermine the elected government, while the LG's office maintains that they are following proper procedures.

item.title: Why is Japan PM Fumio Kishida stepping down? Who could replace him?
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has announced he will not seek re-election as the leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). This decision comes amid declining approval ratings, political scandals, and economic challenges. Kishida acknowledged the impact of these issues on his leadership. Several potential successors have emerged, including Shigeru Ishiba, Taro Kono, Toshimitsu Motegi, Sanae Takaichi, and Yoko Kamikawa. The upcoming leadership contest in September will determine Japan's next prime minister and their approach to addressing the country's domestic and international challenges.

item.title: Why is August 15 National Mourning Day in Bangladesh? Why has interim government scrapped the holiday?
item.description:
In a statement issued after leaving the country, former Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina urged the people to observe August 15 as "National Mourning Day" to commemorate the assassination of her father, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman. This request came shortly after the interim government, led by Muhammad Yunus, decided to cancel the national holiday for the day. August 15 marks the anniversary of the 1975 assassination of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, Bangladesh's first president, and his family members.
The decision to scrap the holiday has been met with mixed reactions, with some attributing it to the public anger directed at Hasina and the recent violence that included the desecration of the Bangabandhu Memorial Museum and the toppling of Rahman's statue.

item.title: Independence Day 2024: Why Pakistan celebrates freedom a day before India
item.description:
Both India and Pakistan gained independence on August 15, 1947, according to the Indian Independence Act. Pakistan's founding father, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, affirmed August 15 as Pakistan's Independence Day in his historic address. Historical records, including Jinnah's oath-taking ceremony and Pakistan's first postage stamps, corroborate this.
Due to logistical constraints during the power transfer, Viceroy Lord Mountbatten officially handed over power to Pakistan in Karachi on August 14, but this does not change the legal date of independence.
Pakistan shifted its Independence Day to August 14 in 1948, likely to distinguish itself from India. This decision was likely made by political leaders aiming to establish a unique national identity for the newly formed country.

item.title: FirstUp: Murmu’s address on I-Day eve, Thai PM faces possible ouster... The big news today
item.description:
President Droupadi Murmu will address the nation on August 14, on the eve of Independence Day, and will also inaugurate Amrit Udyan which will be open to the public. Meanwhile, Manish Sisodia will start a padayatra in Delhi as part of preparations for the Assembly elections. The Allahabad High Court will hear the Gyanvapi mosque committee's reply on a plea for an ASI survey of the mosque's 'wazukhana'.
The MCC will begin NEET UG counselling and the WHO emergency committee will discuss the ongoing mpox outbreak in Africa. The Constitutional Court in Thailand will rule on Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin’s appointment of a cabinet minister with a criminal conviction.

item.title: Why is New Zealand seeing a record number of its citizens leaving?
item.description: New Zealand is experiencing a record number of citizens leaving the country. From the start of 2024 to June, 80,174 citizens departed, almost double the pre-pandemic levels. Economic factors like high unemployment, persistent interest rates, and sluggish growth are driving this exodus. Many are seeking opportunities in Australia, which has a strong economy and offers relocation packages for in-demand professions. The declining number of new arrivals adds to this trend, suggesting a potential shift in New Zealand's attractiveness as a destination.

item.title: Why is there a crackdown on air-conditioners in Italy's Portofino?
item.description:
Portofino, a picturesque Italian coastal village, is facing a battle against air conditioners.
Known for its stunning harbor and luxury lifestyle, Portofino is also a regional park subject to strict regulations. While a ban on ACs once existed, it has recently been relaxed to permit installations with official approval and discreet placement.
Current scorching temperatures have prompted residents to secretly install AC units, leading to neighborly tensions and a police crackdown. The mayor aims to preserve Portofino's aesthetic beauty and environmental integrity, emphasizing the need for discretion and adherence to regulations. Those caught installing units without permission face hefty fines, adding to the controversy surrounding this unexpected conflict.

item.title: 77 years after Independence, how India Inc drives UK's economy
item.description:
The UK is home to 971 Indian-owned firms that employ over 118,000 people and generate $87 billion in revenue. These companies paid $1.5 billion in corporation taxes, a significant increase from previous years.
Indian financial services firms have also made inroads, with six percent of tracked companies falling into this category. Prominent Indian-owned firms in the UK include the St James Court Hotel, EET fuels, and several major pharmaceutical companies. India is the second largest source of Foreign Direct Investment in the UK, creating 8,384 new jobs in 2023.
Major Indian businesses like Tata Group, Reliance Industries, and Wipro have made significant acquisitions in the UK, further strengthening their presence. The UK has also become a popular destination for Indian high-net-worth individuals, with several billionaires purchasing luxury properties in London.

item.title: YouTuber stays awake for almost 250 hours. What sleep deprivation can do to the body
item.description: YouTuber Norme was attempting to break the world record for staying awake, livestreaming for over 250 hours. However, due to severe sleep deprivation, YouTube removed his stream 12 hours before he planned to reach his goal. Norme exhibited symptoms such as passing out, hallucinating, and becoming incoherent. YouTube cited violations of their harmful and dangerous policy. While the Guinness World Records doesn't track no-sleep records due to health risks, Norme continued his attempt on another platform.

item.title: From the sepoy mutiny to Quit India, the key movements that shaped India’s freedom struggle
item.description: India's path to independence was paved by a series of pivotal struggles. The Sepoy Mutiny of 1857, triggered by British policies and religious sensitivities, marked the first major uprising against colonial rule. The Swadeshi Movement, sparked by the partition of Bengal, promoted Indian-made goods and fostered national identity. Gandhi's Champaran Satyagraha, a campaign of non-violent resistance against oppressive land laws, established Satyagraha as a cornerstone of the independence struggle. The Non-Cooperation Movement, launched in 1920, sought to weaken British rule through mass civil disobedience, culminating in the Salt Satyagraha, a dramatic act of defiance against the salt tax. The Quit India Movement of 1942, with its resounding "Do or Die" call, intensified the pressure for independence, ultimately leading to India's freedom on August 15th, 1947.

item.title: How are Yemen's Houthi rebels driving up coffee prices in Europe?
item.description: The price of coffee in Europe has seen a substantial increase, driven by a combination of geopolitical events, climate change, and new regulations. Houthi rebel attacks in the Red Sea have disrupted shipping routes, leading to higher transport costs. The war in Ukraine has further exacerbated the situation by impacting fertilizer supplies and energy prices. Climate change has also played a role, with adverse weather events causing decreased coffee yields in major producing countries. New EU regulations aimed at curbing deforestation have added to the burden on coffee producers, increasing costs and uncertainties. While production is expected to be in surplus next year, the long-term outlook is uncertain due to the ongoing threat of climate change on coffee cultivation.

item.title: I-Day trivia in graphics | Did you know India did not have a national anthem on Aug 15, 1947?
item.description: India will celebrate its 78th Independence Day on August 15th, commemorating the sacrifices made during the freedom struggle. British rule ended in August 1947, but the transition resulted in the partition of India into India and Pakistan. Interestingly, Pakistan got its independence on August 14th, as Lord Mountbatten wished to attend the power transfer ceremonies of both nations.

item.title: Ukraine's incursion into Russia: Why are Ukrainian vehicles marked with white triangles?
item.description:
Ukraine launched a surprise incursion into Russia's Kursk region, marking the biggest cross-border attack since the beginning of the war. Ukrainian forces have reportedly captured 28 settlements and control 1,000 square kilometers of territory.
The operation, shrouded in secrecy, utilizes white triangles as markings on vehicles, distinguishing friendly forces. This tactic mirrors Russia's use of the "Z" symbol during the invasion. Analysts believe the incursion aims to stretch Russian resources, inflict losses, and demonstrate Ukraine's offensive capability. It also serves as a symbolic reminder that the war has reached Russian soil.

item.title: Endless wait, countless hardships: How patients suffer as doctors go on strike to protest Kolkata rape-murder
item.description:
Junior doctors across India are on strike, demanding justice for a 31-year-old junior doctor who was raped and murdered at Kolkata's RG Kar Medical College and Hospital.
They are also pushing for better security measures in hospitals. The strike has significantly disrupted healthcare services, with OPDs closed and elective surgeries postponed, causing immense inconvenience to patients. The horrifying details of the doctor’s death, including evidence of strangulation and severe injuries, have fueled the anger and frustration of medical professionals.
Protests have erupted in various cities, including New Delhi, Mumbai, and Kolkata, with doctors demanding a fast-track investigation into the crime and the resignation of authorities they believe are responsible for inadequate security. They underscore the urgent need for improved safety protocols in hospitals and a stronger legal framework to protect healthcare workers from violence.
The indefinite strike has left patients struggling to access essential medical care, highlighting a critical issue within the healthcare system.

item.title: Explained: Why are multinational corporations fleeing Pakistan?
item.description:
Multinational corporations are leaving Pakistan in large numbers due to a multitude of factors. Economic instability, a complex regulatory environment, high taxation, and political turmoil are all contributing to a decline in investor confidence. Companies like TotalEnergies, Telenor, and Shell Oil have already scaled back or exited the Pakistani market, highlighting the severity of the situation. This trend raises concerns about Pakistan's future ability to attract foreign direct investment and its overall economic prospects.
To reverse this exodus, Pakistan needs to create a more stable and predictable business environment. This requires addressing issues such as regulatory uncertainty, repatriation of profits, and political instability. Without these changes, Pakistan risks further economic decline and continued disillusionment among foreign investors.

item.title: Iran is set to attack Israel. Here’s how it could go down
item.description:
Iran is reported to be planning a retaliation attack against Israel following the assassination of a Hamas leader in Tehran and a senior Hezbollah commander in Beirut.
The US has heightened its military presence in the region, deploying a missile submarine and an aircraft carrier strike group. Experts believe Iran will likely launch a drone and missile attack similar to the one it carried out in April, but may limit the scale to avoid escalating into a full-scale war. Some analysts suggest Iran might coordinate its response with Hezbollah.
While Iran insists its retaliation is unrelated to the Gaza ceasefire, international pressure is mounting to prevent a wider conflict. Experts say both sides may strive to avoid a major confrontation, while also seeking to demonstrate their strength and deter future aggression. Iran's actions are perceived to be aimed at signaling its unwavering resolve and capability.

item.title: Kolkata rape and murder: How hospital misled doctor's family to believe she died by suicide
item.description:
The death of a trainee doctor at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital in Kolkata has sparked outrage. The victim was found semi-naked in a lecture hall with injuries, leading to allegations of rape and murder. Her family claims they were initially told she died by suicide and were not allowed to see her body immediately, raising suspicions of a cover-up.
The police have arrested a community volunteer, Sanjay Roy, who allegedly had access to different hospital departments. The autopsy report revealed sexual assault and injuries consistent with a violent struggle. The incident has led to an indefinite strike by resident doctors nationwide demanding justice and improved safety measures.

item.title: Videos of ‘pregnant cars’ go viral in China. What’s that all about?
item.description: This viral video shows cars in China with bulging exteriors, resembling "pregnant" vehicles. The phenomenon is not due to manufacturing defects but the extreme heatwave gripping the country. Prolonged exposure to high temperatures weakens the adhesive backing of car wraps, causing them to bubble and swell. Experts advise using high-quality wraps with strong adhesives and seeking shade to prevent this issue. While seemingly comical, these "pregnant cars" highlight the growing impact of climate change on everyday life, showcasing the unpredictable consequences of extreme weather events.

item.title: As the Olympic flame extinguishes, what awaits Macron in France’s political quagmire?
item.description:
The Paris Olympics ended on a high note, offering a brief respite from France’s ongoing political divisions. President Macron, however, faces significant challenges as he returns to a hung parliament and pressing budgetary concerns.
Forming a stable government and appointing a new prime minister are immediate priorities. Macron must also address the looming budget crisis, requiring a credible financial plan to avoid penalties from the European Commission.
Despite the successful Olympics, which showcased national unity, Macron's approval ratings remain low and political opposition is likely to intensify. The coming months will be crucial for Macron and his ability to steer France through these turbulent times.

item.title: Liquid water found on Mars: Does this mean there could be life on the Red Planet?
item.description: Scientists have discovered evidence of a vast reservoir of liquid water on Mars, hidden deep within the planet's outer crust. This finding, based on seismic data from NASA's InSight Lander, suggests that the volume of water may exceed that of ancient Martian oceans. The water is believed to be trapped in cracks of igneous rock approximately seven to twelve miles beneath the surface. While this discovery doesn't confirm the existence of life on Mars, it significantly improves our understanding of the planet's history and raises the possibility of habitable environments in its subsurface.

item.title: Who is Faiz Hameed, former ISI chief, who has been arrested by Pakistan army? What are the charges against him?
item.description:
This article reports on the unprecedented arrest and court-martial proceedings initiated against Lt Gen Faiz Hameed, the former chief of Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI). Hameed's arrest stems from allegations of misconduct in a housing scheme scandal known as the Top City case.
He is accused of extortion and misuse of authority during his tenure as ISI chief. The Pakistani Supreme Court ordered an investigation into the allegations, leading to Hameed's arrest and the commencement of court-martial proceedings.
His arrest is seen as a significant development, signifying a crackdown on allies of former Prime Minister Imran Khan and a warning to those who might attempt to weaken the military establishment.

item.title: What is DDOS attack that delayed Donald Trump’s interview with Elon Musk?
item.description: Elon Musk announced that X was the target of a massive DDOS attack, preventing his scheduled interview with former President Donald Trump. The attack aimed to take the platform offline by overwhelming it with traffic. Musk stated that X was working to mitigate the attack and would proceed with a smaller live audience or post the conversation later. Despite the technical difficulties, the interview ultimately took place and covered topics like Trump's interactions with world leaders and his critique of Democrats' policies.

item.title: The Trump-Musk chat on X needed a fact-check: What were the false claims the former US president made?
item.description: Donald Trump made numerous inaccurate or misleading claims during a conversation with Elon Musk on X. He exaggerated border crossing numbers, misrepresented Vice President Kamala Harris's role, and made unsubstantiated claims about other countries releasing criminals into the US. Trump's assertions on energy policy, the economy, and climate change were also flawed, including downplaying the threat of rising sea levels and inflating inflation rates. He continued to make false claims about the 2020 election and the Biden administration's targeting of him politically. Additionally, Trump provided inaccurate information about nuclear weapon possession and misrepresented the amount of aid European countries have provided to Ukraine.

item.title: ‘Why is he lisping?’: How the Trump-Musk chat has raised questions about ex-US president’s health
item.description: Elon Musk and Donald Trump recently had a two-hour interview on X, which garnered attention for Trump's apparent lisp. Many viewers commented on his speech, sparking discussions and speculation about his health. The lisp raised concerns about Trump's fitness for office, especially considering his age (78) and previous health questions. A recent survey showed that a majority of Americans believe Trump is too old to run for president. Despite assurances from his doctor and Trump's own claims of vitality, there's a lack of transparency regarding Trump's health status. This lack of information contrasts with his opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, whose age is less of a concern for the Democratic Party.

item.title: From slurring words to plan for Iron Dome for US, key takeaways from Trump-Musk interview
item.description:
Trump and Elon Musk engaged in a long-awaited conversation plagued by technical difficulties. While the discussion yielded little insight into Trump's second-term plans, several notable themes emerged. Trump's speech patterns drew attention, with some comparisons made to President Biden's stutter. He suggested a potential role for Musk in his administration, praising his efficiency and proposing Musk join a government efficiency commission. Trump reiterated his desire to abolish the Department of Education and voiced his support for establishing an Iron Dome-style missile defense system in the US, similar to Israel's.
The interaction also included Trump's praise for world leaders like Putin, Xi Jinping, and Kim Jong-un, acknowledging their toughness and strategic acumen. Finally, Trump's return to X (formerly Twitter) ahead of the interview signifies a potential boost in his reach and communication platform.

item.title: FirstUp: Vinesh Phogat verdict anticipated, Palestine's Abbas to meet Putin... Top headlines today
item.description: The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) postponed its decision on wrestler Vinesh Phogat's appeal against her disqualification from the Paris 2024 Olympics to August 13th. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas arrived in Moscow for a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss strategies for supporting humanitarian aid efforts in Gaza and enhancing bilateral relations. Google is scheduled to unveil its Pixel 9 series of smartphones at its Made By Google event on August 13th.

item.title: Greece wildfires spread: What's behind the deadly blazes?
item.description: A massive wildfire raging outside Athens forced the evacuation of thousands of residents. Fueled by strong winds, the blaze has burned homes and sent plumes of smoke over the capital. Greece has requested assistance from European countries, with numerous nations sending fire-fighting resources. Experts attribute the severity of the fire to Greece's hot and dry weather combined with climate change, which has increased the frequency and intensity of wildfires in the Mediterranean region. The country has faced record high temperatures this summer, further exacerbating the situation.

item.title: Red, yellow, green and white? Why traffic lights could be getting a new colour
item.description: Experts propose adding a fourth colour, white, to traffic lights to accommodate driverless cars. Autonomous vehicles would be better able to respond to a single white light compared to human drivers who rely on a system of red, yellow, and green. The new system could involve driverless cars communicating with each other and computers, with a white light signaling to human drivers that it is safe to follow the leading self-driving vehicle. This could potentially reduce traffic congestion and improve fuel efficiency.

item.title: After the Paris Games, comes the ‘Olympic comedown’ for athletes. What is it?
item.description:
The end of the Olympic Games often brings a sense of emptiness, known as "Olympic comedown," for athletes. This phenomenon stems from the abrupt shift from a high-pressure, highly stimulating environment to the normalcy of everyday life.
Athletes experience a decrease in adrenaline, which they get from training and competition, leading to feelings similar to withdrawal. They also face an existential crisis as their identity, largely defined by their sport, is challenged.
It's crucial for athletes to prepare mentally and physically for this transition. Recognizing and accepting the end of the competition cycle, taking time to celebrate achievements, and engaging in enjoyable activities outside of sport are essential coping mechanisms.

item.title: Why has Kamala Harris’ laugh become a subject of debate in US election?
item.description:
Trump and Republicans are targeting Kamala Harris' laugh, using derogatory nicknames like "Laughing Kamala" to undermine her. They claim her laughter is inappropriate and try to portray her as unhinged. This tactic is reminiscent of past attacks on women in power, such as Hillary Clinton's "cackle," which were criticized as misogynistic.
Experts suggest that voters are more aware of such tactics today. Some argue that Harris' laughter is a display of strength and authenticity, contrasting with Trump's perceived lack of humor and emotional control. Supporters view it as a joyful expression, while critics perceive it as unprofessional and unbecoming of a leader.

item.title: Was statue of Pakistan army’s surrender in 1971 Liberation War in Bangladesh vandalised?
item.description: Congress MP Shashi Tharoor claimed that statues at a memorial complex in Bangladesh depicting the Pakistani army's surrender to the Indian Army during the 1971 Bangladesh Liberation War have been "destroyed" by "anti-India vandals." He cited images appearing to show broken statues. However, this claim has been challenged, with some pointing out that the statues themselves are designed to depict people lying down as a symbol of the atrocities committed during the war. They argue that the images shared by Tharoor show the intended artistic representation, not vandalism.

item.title: Independence Day 2024: How India and Pakistan divided money, military and an elephant amid partition
item.description:
The Partition of India in 1947 led to a massive task of dividing assets between India and Pakistan. A committee, the Partition Council, was formed with representatives from both sides to oversee the division.
A significant challenge was splitting the military, with two-thirds staying in India and one-third going to Pakistan. The division was not without its tensions, as exemplified by the case of the Brigade of Gurkhas and the exchange of troops between units.
Financial assets were divided according to the Partition agreement, with Pakistan receiving 17.5%. The process of exchanging currency and settling debts proved complex and controversial, with both countries claiming outstanding payments. Beyond military and financial assets, movable assets like furniture and even light bulbs were divided in an 80-20 ratio.
Even animals were included in the division, as illustrated by the case of Joymoni, an elephant whose ownership was a subject of dispute. The Partition Council successfully navigated these intricate challenges, ultimately achieving a division of assets despite the complexities and difficulties inherent in the process.

item.title: What does crash of 'unauthorised' helicopter flight mean for Australia's tourists?
item.description: A helicopter crashed into the roof of the DoubleTree by Hilton hotel in Cairns, Australia, killing one person and injuring two others with smoke inhalation. The incident occurred around 1:50 am, during peak tourist season. The helicopter, described by witnesses as flying low and without lights, hit the building, causing a fire and prompting the evacuation of 400 guests. Authorities are investigating the circumstances of the crash, including the pilot's qualifications and authorization for the flight. The hotel remains closed for structural assessment.

item.title: All that glitters is not gold: What’s the real value of an Olympic medal?
item.description: Olympic medals, while symbolizing athletic excellence, hold a surprisingly modest intrinsic value. The Paris 2024 gold medal, for example, contains only 6 grams of gold and is valued at around $1,027. While the material value is relatively low, the historical significance and the stories connected to these medals can drive their auction prices to millions. Examples include medals from Jesse Owens, Bob Beamon, and Luz Long, which have fetched impressive sums at auctions, highlighting the enduring legacy and cultural impact of Olympic achievements.

item.title: World Elephant Day: How railway tracks have become graveyards for jumbos in India
item.description:
India is home to a significant population of Asian elephants, but these majestic creatures face a growing threat from train collisions. In the past decade, at least 200 elephants have perished in such accidents.
To address this issue, authorities are implementing various safety measures. Tamil Nadu has deployed an AI-based surveillance system to alert authorities of elephant movement near tracks, while the national government plans to roll out a similar system across a 700-km stretch. States are also constructing wildlife overpasses to provide safe passage for elephants.
Despite these efforts, challenges remain. The vast network of Indian Railways, coupled with development priorities, frequently intersects with elephant corridors, increasing the risk of collisions. Experts suggest further measures such as reducing night-time train operations, ensuring adequate food and water within forests, and implementing strict speed controls in areas prone to accidents.

item.title: How attacks on Hindus in Bangladesh is the first big test for Yunus-led interim government
item.description:
The escalating violence against Hindus in Bangladesh following the ousting of Sheikh Hasina has sparked international concern. Protests demanding justice and protection materialized in both the US and the UK, with demonstrators highlighting the attacks on temples, businesses, and homes, as well as the killing of two prominent Hindu leaders.
In Bangladesh, rallies drew sizable crowds, with people protesting the attacks and urging the interim government to address the situation. The government has expressed concern, promised to investigate, and pledged financial aid to the affected families, but has also issued warnings against the spread of misinformation.
Meanwhile, prominent Indian-American lawmakers have called for an end to the violence and emphasized the need to hold perpetrators accountable. They urged the US government to take a proactive role in ensuring the safety of minorities in Bangladesh.

item.title: How Ukraine’s incursion of Kursk has left Putin humiliated
item.description:
Ukraine launched a surprise cross-border attack into Russia's Kursk region, pushing nearly 1,000 troops supported by tanks and artillery deep into Russian territory. The operation has caught Russia off guard, forcing thousands of residents to evacuate and prompting the Kremlin to declare a state of emergency. Ukrainian forces have captured strategic positions, destroying Russian military vehicles and inflicting casualties.
The incursion has been hailed as a success by Ukraine, showcasing their military capability and boosting morale. It has also exposed weaknesses in Russia's border defenses and dealt a blow to Putin's image of invincibility. While Ukraine's plans remain unclear, the operation has already achieved significant strategic objectives by diverting Russian resources and highlighting Ukraine's resilience.

item.title: What are the new allegations Hindenburg has levelled against Sebi chief and Adani?
item.description:
The ongoing Hindenburg vs Adani Group saga intensifies with fresh allegations from Hindenburg Research. The US-based firm claims that Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) chief Madhabi Puri Buch and her husband, Dhaval Buch, had stakes in offshore entities linked to the Adani family, potentially constituting a conflict of interest.
Hindenburg cites "whistleblower documents" to support its claim, alleging that these funds were used for financial irregularities within the Adani Group. Sebi chief Madhabi Buch and her husband vehemently deny the allegations, asserting the transparency of their financial dealings and highlighting that their investments predate Buch's appointment at Sebi. They claim they sold off their stakes in 2018 upon the CIO's departure from the fund and reiterate their commitment to ethical conduct, labelling Hindenburg's accusations as baseless.
The Hindenburg report, however, raises concerns about a potential conflict of interest given Buch's role in overseeing investigations related to the Adani Group. This new development has triggered a decline in Adani Group stocks, with investors losing billions of rupees amid market uncertainty.

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas to visit Russia today: What do we know about the relationship between Moscow and Palestine?
item.description:
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas will visit Russia from August 12 to 14, his first trip since 2021. Ties between the two nations date back to 1974, when the Palestinian Liberation Organisation opened a branch in Moscow. Russia has consistently supported the two-state solution and a Palestinian state, while maintaining a neutral stance as a mediator in the region. However, Recent events, including Russia's support for Hamas and its strained relationship with Israel, have raised questions about its ability to effectively mediate.
Abbas' visit aims to discuss the latest international developments, coordinate positions, and strengthen bilateral relations.

item.title: Bangladesh crisis: What could the US gain from acquiring St. Martin's Island?
item.description: St. Martin's Island, a small Bangladeshi island in the Bay of Bengal, has become a geopolitical flashpoint. Former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina claimed the US sought to acquire the island in exchange for political support, a claim her son denied and the US State Department refuted. The island's strategic location near crucial maritime routes makes it highly valuable, potentially allowing for surveillance of Chinese activity and control of vital trade routes. While Bangladesh benefits economically from the island's resources and tourism, maritime boundary disputes with Myanmar add complexity. The island's potential for a US military presence raises concerns among neighboring countries, including India and China, who are also vying for influence in the region.

item.title: Civic volunteer, history of drinking, had porn on phone: Inside details about the accused in Kolkata hospital rape-murder case
item.description:
The Kolkata Police arrested Sanjay Roy, a civic volunteer, for the rape and murder of a 31-year-old trainee doctor at RG Kar Medical College and Hospital. Roy had access to the hospital premises and was allegedly drunk at the time of the crime.
CCTV footage showed Roy entering the building around 4 am and leaving 40 minutes later without his Bluetooth device, which was found near the scene of the crime. Blood found on his shoes also serves as evidence. He allegedly attempted to destroy evidence by washing his clothes.
The autopsy report confirmed sexual assault and revealed multiple injuries on the victim's body, indicating a violent struggle. Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee has ordered a fast-track trial and seeks the death penalty for the accused. She has also offered a CBI probe if the family desires it. The incident has sparked protests and called for improved security measures for medical staff.

item.title: FirstUp: Palestinian President Abbas to visit Russia, Trump’s major interview with Elon Musk
item.description: Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas will visit Russia from August 12 to 14, his first trip to Moscow since 2021. The visit comes as Russia has relationships with both Israel and Hamas, and hosted unity talks between Palestinian factions in March. The Budget session of the Indian Parliament has concluded, with the government introducing 11 bills and passing three. The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear pleas from BRS leader K Kavitha challenging the denial of her bail in corruption and money laundering cases linked to the Delhi excise policy scam. Meanwhile, Donald Trump will be interviewed by Elon Musk on August 12. The Election Commission will visit Haryana on August 12 and 13 to review preparations for the upcoming Assembly elections.

item.title: Explained: How USA's Jordan Chiles lost bronze medal for floor exercise at Paris Olympics
item.description:
During the Paris Olympics, a scoring controversy erupted in the women’s floor exercise. American Jordan Chiles initially won the bronze medal after her coach appealed a score, boosting her placement. However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) ruled the appeal was made outside the allowed timeframe, reinstating the original ranking. This awarded the bronze medal to Romania’s Ana Barbosu. Romanian gymnast Sabrina Maneca-Voinea, who was initially placed fourth, also appealed a penalty but was denied.
The controversy resulted in criticism directed at Chiles, with some calling for her to return the medal. Both Barbosu and Chiles received support from fellow gymnasts like Simone Biles and Sunisa Lee, who emphasized the importance of fair judging.

item.title: How Albanian jeweller's $1.4 million watch pays homage to the history of his county
item.description: Pirro Ruco, an Albanian jeweller, has designed a luxury watch that will compete at the Geneva Watchmaking Grand Prix. Ruco's success mirrors Albania's transformation from a communist regime to a capitalist nation. He overcame challenges including accusations of working with foreign agents and the political upheaval that followed the collapse of communism. Ruco's watch, "Primordial Passion," features Albanian folk dancers, an eagle talon minute hand, and a sapphire dome. He hopes the intricate design and attention to detail will earn recognition at the prestigious competition.

item.title: Gen X and millennials at greater risk of cancer than older generations. Here’s why
item.description:
A recent study by the American Cancer Society found that Gen X and millennials are at increased risk for 17 types of cancer compared to older generations. This includes cancers of the small intestine, thyroid, kidney, and pancreas. The study analyzed data from nearly 24 million cancer patients and concluded that younger generations are developing these cancers at younger ages.
Researchers attribute this trend to lifestyle changes, such as increased obesity and sedentary behavior, as well as altered dietary habits with more ultra-processed foods. Binge drinking, particularly among millennial women, was also identified as a contributing factor to liver and esophageal cancer rates. The study highlights the importance of understanding the causes of these rising cancer rates to develop effective prevention strategies. However, the study also noted positive trends, such as a decrease in lung and melanoma cancer rates, demonstrating the impact of public health campaigns promoting smoking cessation and sun-safe practices.

item.title: Is Mercury retrograde really to blame for life's chaos? What is it?
item.description:
Mercury retrograde, an astrological phenomenon where Mercury appears to move backward in its orbit, is believed to disrupt communication, travel, and technology. This perceived backward motion occurs because Mercury orbits the Sun faster than Earth.
Astrologically, Mercury governs communication, travel, technology, and information. During retrograde, these areas are thought to be prone to disruptions like miscommunications, travel delays, and technological malfunctions.
While there's no scientific evidence to support these claims, many people believe that Mercury retrograde can impact their lives negatively. To navigate this period, astrologers recommend exercising extra caution, avoiding major decisions, backing up technology, and staying flexible.

item.title: Cats vs toddlers: Are Chinese youth choosing pets over kids?
item.description: A Goldman Sachs report predicts that China's urban pet population will surpass the number of young children by 2030. The report attributes this trend to declining birth rates in China, with urban pet ownership projected to reach 70 million by 2030, compared to a child population under four years old of less than 40 million. This boom in pet ownership is expected to fuel a significant growth in the pet food market, reaching $12 billion by 2030. The report also notes that cat ownership is predicted to surpass dog ownership due to space constraints. China's shrinking population and declining birth rates are a major concern, driven by factors such as economic instability, pandemic effects, and the high cost of raising a family. To combat this, the government is implementing various incentives to encourage childbirth, but young people cite financial concerns as a primary deterrent.

item.title: This Week in Explainers: Will Sheikh Hasina return to Bangladesh and politics?
item.description: A military coup in Bangladesh has ousted Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, forcing her to flee the country. The coup followed weeks of anti-government protests. Hasina has sought refuge in India, but her future and that of Bangladesh remain uncertain. A caretaker government, led by Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus, is now in power. Meanwhile, the UK continues to grapple with a wave of far-right violence sparked by recent stabbings. Anti-racism protests have emerged in response. In the US, Kamala Harris has chosen Tim Walz as her running mate, sparking debate over a controversial passage in Vance's memoir. Other global stories include a proposed law in Iraq that would lower the legal age of marriage, and the delayed return of Indian-American astronaut Sunita Williams from the International Space Station.

item.title: 6 murals in 7 days. What's street artist Banksy up to in the UK?
item.description:
Banksy has recently unveiled a series of six animal-themed murals across London, sparking curiosity and debate about their meaning. The striking silhouettes, ranging from goats and elephants to wolves and pelicans, have been placed in various locations, with the artist providing no accompanying captions.
Speculation abounds regarding the message behind the artworks, with some linking them to social and political issues such as far-right violence, environmental crises, and the state of global politics. Banksy has often used animals in his work to convey messages about animal welfare, climate change, and threats to the environment. The rapidity with which these murals appeared is unusual for the elusive artist, who typically releases work in spaced intervals.

item.title: Junior doctor raped and murdered in Kolkata: What's going on?
item.description:
A second-year medical student was found dead in a seminar hall of a state-run hospital in Kolkata. The student was on night duty and was last seen by colleagues around 2 am. Her body was discovered around 7:30 am by an intern and showed signs of a struggle, including scratch marks and injuries. Police have arrested one person based on CCTV footage and formed a Special Investigation Team.
The incident has sparked outrage, with students demanding a faster investigation, security improvements, and action against the culprits. Protests have been organized by medical professionals, students, and political parties. The Chief Minister assured the victim's family of all help to ensure justice and has directed the case to be taken to a fast-track court.

item.title: What we know and what we don't about the Brazil plane crash that killed 61
item.description: A Voepass flight crashed near Sao Paulo, Brazil, killing all 61 people onboard. The ATR-72 aircraft experienced a rapid descent, plummeting roughly 17,000 feet in one minute before hitting a residential area. Authorities are investigating the cause, with initial speculation focusing on potential ice buildup on the plane, a possibility that echoes a similar 1994 incident. Other theories include engine failure, flight control system malfunctions, or a critical component failure. The recovered black box could provide vital clues to understanding the crash.

item.title: Your microwave is full of bacteria. Does it make it a health hazard?
item.description: A recent study investigated the presence of bacteria in microwaves from various environments like homes, offices, and laboratories. Researchers discovered 747 different bacterial genera, with Firmicutes, Actinobacteria, and Proteobacteria being the most prevalent. Microbes found in domestic and shared microwaves were similar to those found on kitchen surfaces, suggesting food particles may offer protection from radiation. In contrast, laboratory microwaves harbored distinct bacteria resembling those found in extreme environments. The study highlighted that some bacteria, like Klebsiella, Enterococcus, and Aeromonas, present in domestic microwaves could pose health risks.

item.title: This Week in Explainers: Why changes in Waqf Act have sparked uproar
item.description:
The Waqf (Amendment) Bill, which proposes over 30 changes to the 1995 Waqf Act, was introduced in the Lok Sabha and faced strong opposition. The bill has sparked controversy with opposition parties accusing the government of attacking the Constitution and federalism.
Bangladesh's Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fled the country and sought refuge in India. Her stay, initially expected to be temporary, might be extended as her asylum request to the UK faces hurdles.
Manish Sisodia, former Delhi deputy chief minister, was granted bail by the Supreme Court in cases connected to the Delhi excise policy scam, offering a significant boost to the AAP.
Meanwhile, Vinesh Phogat's disqualification from the Paris Olympics for being overweight triggered widespread concern and speculation about potential bias.
Concerns surfaced regarding the impact of Bangladesh's political turmoil on India's trade relations, as bilateral trade was disrupted due to the crisis. Kerala reported a surge in cases of amoebic meningoencephalitis, a rare and deadly brain infection, raising public health concerns.

item.title: America is facing a major blood shortage. Here’s why heat is to blame
item.description: The US national blood supply has dropped by over 25% since July 1st due to extreme heat impacting blood drives. The Red Cross, which provides 40% of the country's blood donations, is urging people to donate, emphasizing the need for type O blood, particularly in emergencies. The heat wave has led to cancellations and low turnout at blood drives, resulting in a deficit of approximately 19,000 donations in July. Hurricane season further compounds the issue, potentially disrupting collection efforts. Experts warn that the shortage could impact critical medical treatments, including surgeries, childbirth complications, and care for patients with trauma, cancer, and blood disorders. The Red Cross is offering a $20 Amazon gift card to encourage donations.

item.title: The Netherlands has prisons that are too ‘empty’. Here's why
item.description:
The Netherlands is facing a unique problem: severely underpopulated prisons. This is due to remarkably low crime rates and a focus on rehabilitation over punishment. The country has implemented shorter sentences for non-violent crimes, with many serving less than three months. There is a strong belief that prison can be more detrimental than beneficial.
The Dutch system emphasizes alternatives like electronic tagging and specialized mental health treatment programs to reduce recidivism. As a result, the prison population has been dramatically reduced, leading to the closure of numerous facilities and their repurposing for other societal needs.

item.title: Can mayonnaise hold the key to unlocking nuclear fusion? Scientists think so...
item.description:
Researchers at Lehigh University are using mayonnaise to study the challenges of nuclear fusion. Mayonnaise, which behaves like a solid until subjected to pressure, mimics the behavior of plasma, the charged state of matter involved in fusion.
The research focuses on understanding how hydrodynamic instabilities, particularly the Rayleigh-Taylor instability, affect fusion reactions. These instabilities can reduce the efficiency of fusion energy production.
By studying how mayonnaise flows and becomes unstable under pressure, the researchers aim to develop strategies to predict, control, and potentially suppress these instabilities in actual fusion experiments. This knowledge could lead to significant improvements in the efficiency of fusion energy generation.

item.title: Do Nobel winners make good leaders? As Muhammad Yunus helms Bangladesh, a look at history
item.description: The path from Nobel Peace Prize laureate to political leader can be complex and varied. Figures like Aung San Suu Kyi, who faced controversy during her time as Myanmar's de facto leader, and Nelson Mandela, who successfully led South Africa's transition from apartheid, demonstrate the challenges and potential triumphs involved. Other laureates, such as JosÃ© Ramos-Horta, have found success in guiding their nations through peaceful development. Economist Muhammad Yunus's recent appointment as Bangladesh's interim leader adds another dimension to this conversation, raising questions about his ability to navigate the country's turbulent political landscape.

item.title: Mirabai Chanu says she lost Olympic medal due to periods. Here’s how athletes manage menstruation
item.description:
Mirabai Chanu's admission of feeling weak during the Paris Olympics due to menstruation has sparked a conversation about the impact of periods on athletic performance. Numerous female athletes have spoken about the challenges they face, including pain, cramps, fatigue, and mood swings.
Research suggests fluctuations in female hormones can affect muscle activation, metabolism, and increase the risk of injury. Athletes often use period trackers, adjust training regimens, and even consider hormonal contraceptives to manage their cycles.
Experts emphasize the importance of adequate rest, hydration, proper nutrition, and understanding from coaches to help athletes perform optimally despite the challenges menstruation presents.

item.title: Why is S Jaishankar's Male visit significant for India-Maldives ties?
item.description:
S Jaishankar's visit to the Maldives aims to strengthen bilateral ties that had faced strain following the election of President Mohamed Muizzu. Muizzu, who campaigned on an 'India out' platform, has since visited India for Modi's swearing-in ceremony and met with the Maldivian Foreign Minister and Indian officials in Kampala.
Despite initial reservations about India, the Maldives has requested financial assistance from India, and New Delhi has provided a $50 million loan and eased export restrictions on essential goods. This visit seeks to build upon the previous government's strong defense and security cooperation with India.
While questions remain about Muizzu's long-term policy stance, his actions suggest a more nuanced approach, potentially influenced by the economic challenges facing the Maldives. His administration's dealings with China, meanwhile, are subject to close observation.

item.title: At 84, Bangladesh’s Prof Yunus is older than Biden. Who are other aged world leaders?
item.description:
The article discusses the increasing prevalence of gerontocracy in global politics, focusing on leaders aged 70 and above. It highlights the cases of Paul Biya, Cameroon's 91-year-old president, King Salman of Saudi Arabia (88), and Muhammad Yunus, the 84-year-old head of Bangladesh's interim government.
The article also mentions the age-related challenges faced by Joe Biden, who stepped down from the US presidential race at 81, and examines how other world leaders like Narendra Modi (73), Shehbaz Sharif (72), Vladimir Putin (71), and Xi Jinping (71) navigate their positions despite their advanced age.

item.title: Is a megaquake coming to Japan? How ready is the country for it?
item.description:
Japan experienced a 7.1 magnitude earthquake off its southern coast, triggering a tsunami advisory. Following this tremor, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued its first-ever warning about a potential major earthquake in the near future. The warning, citing a higher risk of an earthquake along the Nankai Trough, emphasized the potential for widespread shaking and tsunami waves impacting coastal areas from Tokyo to Okinawa.
Prime Minister Fumio Kishida canceled his Central Asia trip in response to the warning. Despite past devastating earthquakes, Japan has implemented strict earthquake-resistant building codes and widespread preparedness measures. Buildings are designed to withstand significant shaking, and the country has an effective early warning system and well-rehearsed evacuation protocols.
However, experts acknowledge that it remains impossible to guarantee building safety against a major earthquake until it occurs. The potential impact of a major earthquake on Japan's infrastructure and economy is significant, with estimates of billions of dollars in potential damage.

item.title: Terror threat at Taylor Swift’s Vienna concerts: Who are the ‘ISIS-inspired’ teen suspects?
item.description:
Austrian authorities foiled a terror attack planned for Taylor Swift's concerts in Vienna, leading to the arrest of three teenage suspects. The 19-year-old, described as radicalized towards ISIS, confessed to planning a bombing and stabbing attack using explosives and knives.
He had stockpiled chemicals, detonators, and weapons, and allegedly researched bomb-making techniques from jihadist videos.
Two other teenagers, aged 17 and 15, were also arrested, with the 17-year-old suspected of planning to detonate a bomb at the concert venue.
Due to the threat, three sold-out concerts were cancelled, impacting an estimated 170,000 fans and prompting heightened security across Austria.

item.title: NYT calls violence against Hindus in Bangladesh ‘revenge attacks’: How Western media gets the India story wrong
item.description:
The New York Times drew criticism for its initial headline on violence against Hindus in Bangladesh following the departure of former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. The headline, which labeled the attacks as "revenge," sparked outrage on social media, leading the newspaper to revise it.
This incident isn't the first time the NYT has faced backlash for its coverage of India. Past controversies include a cartoon in 2014 depicting India in a stereotypical manner and opinion pieces alleging curbs on press freedom in Kashmir. The NYT's coverage of India and such incidents highlight a broader concern about Western media bias against the country.
